matches.article_title: Btw 1993 and 2023, the share of American female high school seniors who reported wanting to get married “someday” fell from 83% to 61%. Their male counterparts saw just a 2pp decline to 74%.

.@gchodorowreich @omzidar Eric Zwick and Matthew Smith find firms that benefited from the corporate tax cuts in the 2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act responded with a 20% increase in investment relative to firms that were not impacted.

77% of wealthy Americans grew up middle class or poor, highlighting significant upward mobility. 20% grew up poor, while 45% of millennials came from wealthy families, indicating a generational shift in wealth origins.
The US accounted for 54% of global VC investment in 2018, a decline from previous years, with $130.9bn invested in 2018, up from $84bn in 2017.

In 1990, Sub-Saharan Africa's GDP per capita was 30% of the world average. Btw 2014 and 2022, GDP per capita declined to 22% of the world’s mean. 50% of the world’s population growth over the next 15 years will occur in Africa.
70% of 30-year-olds are outperforming their parents in lifecycle economic achievements, challenging the belief that economic mobility has ended.

As the Fed’s cutting cycle likely renews amid indicators of labor market weakening, measures of core inflation remain above 3%. John Authers notes, "The Fed is going to cut, and there is a strong case for it to do so...the risk ahead is stagflation."

A 10-percentile increase in a person's polygenic index (PGI) raises that person's income by 0.9 percentiles and that of their child by 0.7 percentiles; ~1/2 is direct genetic transmission, and ~ 1/2 the effect of parent’s genes on nurturing capacity.

AI’s share of US GDP increased from 2.4pp in 2013 to 3.5pp in 2023. Data processing nearly doubled its share, while that of manufacturing declined by 1.5pp. Labor productivity in the AI sector, driven by CAPEX, grew 4x the rate of the economy as a whole.

Research by @ErikHurst finds college major choice has strong predictive power in explaining gender wage gaps, independent of occupation choice, accounting for 40% of the decline in the wage gap across birth cohorts.

Consultancy EY estimates that increased European equipment spending on Europe’s domestic defence sector and associated supply chain will increase the EU’s overall manufacturing sector by ~1.5% and create 500,000 jobs.

There is no such thing as an “all-American” car, as the import content often exceeds 70%. Citing the 25% "chicken tax" on truck imports imposed in 1964, Joseph Politano speculates that car tariffs may prove "more durable than most of Trump’s tariffs."
China GDP overstatement: Growth inflated +1.7%/yr (2008-16), economy 12% smaller than reported. Debt/GDP ratio understated by 30bps, investment rate off by 7pp.
Genetic g factor accounts for 58.36% of genetic variance across seven cognitive traits, highlighting its significant role in cognitive performance.
Research productivity in Germany and China has declined by 5% and 3% annually since 2010, respectively, despite significant R&D investments.

While foreigners resumed buying US stocks, bond investors continued selling through April 16, contributing to the dollar depreciation. Insurance companies and pension funds are not hedge funds, and do not make quick asset reallocations. @jnordvig
The US can sustain a maximum government debt to GDP ratio of 220% within a "Goldilocks zone" where interest rates remain below growth rates, allowing for fiscal sustainability.

Polling data show that the share of Americans who believe in American exceptionalism has consistently declined over the past 70 years. Just from 2011 to 2024, the number of respondents claiming there are other countries greater than the US tripled.
@AEI: From 1967 to 2020, children in the bottom income quintile saw a 27pt decline in living with married parents, peaking at 31% in 1992 before rising to 36% by 2020.

Investment funds’ participation in Treasury auctions rose from 1.7% to 67.8% btw Jan. 2008 and Oct. 2023, largely replacing broker-dealers. Commensurate extension of Fed open market operations to non-bank institutions could improve market liquidity.

James Mackintosh notes that the historical tendency for the total return of high investment firms to lag those with lower investment noted by Fama and French continues to hold, “with higher-spending big companies tending to underperform a little.”
The EUR/$ has risen from 1.04 to 1.17 since January 2025. Robin Brooks warns: “Rapid strengthening in the Euro should worry ECB policy makers…because it constitutes a substantial deflationary shock.”

Between 2017 and 2021, only 17% of $150B of Chinese trade financing was denominated in RMB. Since 2022, $100B in trade financing has been RMB denominated, opening up an avenue for China to de-dollarize.

Hindo and Riseley suggest that inflation risk is “tilted asymmetrically to the upside and centered higher than the 2010s.” A continuation of the 4% per year inflation of the first half of the 2020s would represent a “return to baseline.”

Taiwan’s bond portfolio, heavy in low-interest, long-duration bonds, has lost ~12% of its value in dollar terms since 2022 as rates rose. “Appreciation warranted by balance of payments fundamentals,” Setser notes, “may put financial stability at risk.”

Analysis by @RobertGordon suggests pandemic-era productivity gains were due to temporary reallocation effect, not new innovations, with long-term growth likely reverting to pre-pandemic trends. @nberpub.
Large firms in advanced economies significantly influence household economics, with consumers capturing $0.40 per dollar of corporate revenue as surplus and $0.25 in wages/benefits.

2000-16: US labor share -5.4pts = 75% of post-WWII drop. Drivers: sector cycles 33%, depreciation 26%, industry consolidation 18%, automation 12%, globalization 11%. Cost to workers: -$3,000/yr real wages.
Education quality outweighs quantity for growth: PISA/PIAAC data shows 3-4x stronger elasticity vs years studied. Quality improvements drive productivity gains more than increased education years.

Research by @Debopam Bhattacharya shows that controlling for AFQT scores significantly reduces the racial gap in intergenerational mobility, suggesting that these scores reflect accumulated differences in family background rather than innate abilities.

A Pew study finds that only 15% of Americans trust the Federal government to do what is right “most of the time,” down from ~75% in 1960. A secular drop occurred during the Johnson and Nixon years; economic fluctuations account for cyclical variation.

Cochrane relays an exchange with a CEO of a large retailer. “We have to raise prices roughly 10–15% to cover tariffs. [We] will start to see the margin hits a little in Q3 and a lot in Q4. But…we are all trying to hold prices through the key holiday.”
A 3x3 matrix organizes policies to reduce inequality, focusing on target income groups & stages of economic intervention, distinguishing btw pre-distribution & redistribution policies.
Global savings glut drove the U.S. net foreign asset position from -9% of GDP in 2002 to -76% of GDP in 2016, based on 2002 units.
According to @JonathanHuebnerm, the rate of important innovation peaked in 1873 and has been declining since, driven by economic limits of technology or human constraints in information processing.

Bequeathable wealth/GDP has risen from 256% to 424% over 1997- 2021, but the current estate tax law yields ~$0 revenue. @BrookingsInst researchers propose an inheritance tax on recipients that may be more efficient than a revised estate tax.

@JasonFurman and @LHSummers argue that traditional debt-to-GDP ratios are inadequate for assessing fiscal sustainability in an era of low interest rates. Nominal or real interest payments as a share of GDP provide a more accurate measure.
A 1% rise in corporate tax rates is associated with a 0.5% drop in wages, indicating that the burden of corporate tax falls heavily on workers.

.@chris_d_clayton, @m_maggiori, and @JSchrege warn that U.S. financial “hegemony” may be limited by nonlinearity. “Small reductions in American control of the international financial system come with significant reductions in American power.”

.@DrenikAndres et al argue that surging supply-induced inflation in 2021-22 reduced workers’ real wages and incentivized job-to-job transitions that led to a rise in aggregate vacancies, “even when labor markets are not particularly ‘hot.’”

A WSJ analysis found insurers rated by Demotech were 30x as likely to become insolvent as those graded by its main rivals. Demotech-rated insurers collect ~50% of all home-related premia paid in Florida.
R&D tax credits and skilled immigration are the most effective policy tools to promote innovation, according to @NicholasBloom, @JohnVanReenen, and @HeidiWilliams.

The rise in long-term Treasury yields likely reflects the global rise in rates rather than a US-specific "Trump risk premium," Robin Brooks argues, citing the stability of the US trade-weighted yield differential relative to other advanced economies.
The dollar is down 11% since the start of the year. Robin Brooks argues that the decline is not a function of an increased risk premium but "maps almost entirely into interest differentials."

Research by @NathanielHendren shows investing in children yields significant long-term economic benefits, with each $1 spent returning $1.78 to the government through increased tax revenue and reduced transfer payments.

Torsten Sløk and team argue the US is "unlikely" to face a debt crisis: "More likely is gradually higher long-term interest rates, and a steepening of the yield curve." Interest is forecast to rise from 13% of Federal spending in 2024 to 23% in 2054.

.@SteveMiran cites the 2018-19 experience with tariffs on China and $/Yuan exchange rates and argues that increased tariffs will be largely offset by $/Yuan moves, resulting in little net change in after-tariff dollar import prices.
Research challenges the "deaths of despair" narrative, finding opioid use is linked to employment in coal mining, not unemployment. A 1% rise in miner workforce share boosts opioid deaths by 0.192%.

Data from 444 public & 688 private colleges shows average median earnings 10 years post-enrollment vary notably across demographic groups. Black & Pell-eligible students are more prevalent in institutions with lower earnings.
Market power and macroeconomic risk may have driven a rising equity risk premium since 2000, according to @EmmanuelFarhiy.
Wealth inequality drivers quantified: Estate tax elimination raises output +0.35%, capital +0.87%, Gini index 0.79→0.80. Model shows circumstances, not inheritance, drive US earnings/wealth gaps

.@DAcemogluMIT and @baselinescene cite 19th-century textile automation to argue that AI may raise productivity but fail to increase employment and wages as it displaces workers and degrades the quality of remaining jobs.

At current 5-year yields, stabilizing debt/GDP would require a reduction in the primary deficit of 2.3% of GDP in the UK and the US, and 3% in France. Maturing American debt will be refinanced at rates ~200bps higher than today’s.

TFP growth may be linear rather than exponential, challenging traditional growth models, according to @marginalrevolution. @tylercowen discusses Thomas Philippon's research on TFP increments and its implications for economic analysis.
US Total Factor Productivity (TFP) has grown linearly over the past 90 years, challenging the notion of a TFP slowdown.

The analysis of U.S. PIAAC numeracy scores reveals significant regional disparities in advanced cognitive skills, with notable "deserts" in areas like Appalachia & the Ozarks, where only 0-17% of adults possess such skills.
The housing affordability crisis in LA depresses GDP by over 2%, translating into $18bn to $22bn in lost output annually for the City of LA, and nearly double for LA County.

Sub-Saharan Africa’s population, currently ~1.3B, is forecast to reach ~3.5B in 75 years. ~60% of the population is < 25. Worryingly, a Bloomberg analysis finds that between 2005 and 2020, for every two new working-age persons only one job was created.
The administration will appeal to the Supreme Court an appellate court ruling that the International Emergency Economic Powers Act does not allow the President to impose broad import taxes.

Civil rights protest strategy impacts voter behavior: Violent protests shift white vote GOP +1.6-7.9%, while non-violent drives Dem support +1.3-1.6%. 1960-72 data shows protest tactics shape electoral outcomes.
Construction sector accounts for 30% of decline in TFP growth. Sector-specific disturbances have reduced trend GDP growth by 2-3pp over last 6 decades.
Aging workforce dampens productivity: Study projects -3-9% output decline next decade. Older worker concentration reduces individual wages, signals broader economic growth challenge.

Using Nvidia’s datacenter revenue as a reference for US AI capex, @JensNordvig estimates that AI will make up ~2% of US GDP in 2025 given a standard multiplier, implying an AI contribution to GDP growth of 0.7% in 2025.

Research by @DaronAcemoglu finds the overall impact of AI on US employment remains limited, with AI hiring itself the only significant effect on employment patterns & wages. AI exposure has no discernible relationship with employment or wage growth.

The unemployment rate for the quintile of workers most exposed to AI rose 0.30pp between 2022 and early 2025, but for the least-exposed quintile it climbed 0.94pp. “By the most obvious measures, the effect of AI on jobs is invisible.”

Morgan Stanley estimates that the largest public firms will see their EBIT profit pool rise 5% as AI diffuses through the economy. Their model implies that the profit pool of the top quartile of firms by adaptation will rise by 16%.

While CAPE is at 40, higher than its 1929 level, adjusting equity values for last year's profitability suggests the market’s value is less “overstretched” than it was then. Still, it remains ~ at the 95th percentile of its historical distribution.

JPM estimates that to meet an IRR hurdle of 10% on their forecast AI investment through 2030 would require ~$650B in annual revenue in perpetuity. That would be 58bps of global GDP, or $34.72/month from every current iPhone user.
As AI-related real private fixed investment has surged, non-AI-related investment’s contribution to US real private fixed investment has turned negative.
The US built 888 miles of new high-voltage transmission lines in 2024, less than the 2015–2019 mean of 900 miles and the 2009–2014 mean of 1,700 miles.

PJM, the largest grid operator whose coverage includes "data center alley" in VA, announced a 22% y/y increase in the cost of procuring energy supplies and projects a 1–5% rise in customers’ energy bills.

A new combined cycle-gas plant cost ~$800 a kilowatt in 2021, but is ~$2,600–2,800 today due to supply constraints. Siemens, GE Vernova and Mitsubishi Heavy account for 70% of global gas turbine production capacity and are struggling to increase capacity.

Since the release of ChatGPT in November of 2022, earnings per share of the MAG 7 have risen 125% (through 8/18), while earnings per share of the other 493 companies comprising the S&P 500 have risen just 4%.

Between 2018–19 and 2023–25, Americans aged 22–27 with a bachelor's degree saw a steep increase in their unemployment rate from 3.8% to 4.9%, while their high school peers' unemployment rate increased by just 0.1% to 7.3%.

An additional senator or representative per mm residents predicted about $1,000 dollars in additional COVID aid per capita over 2020-2022, yielding incumbents an extra 4 ppt of the two-candidate vote share. @jeffreypclemens @payson_julia @stanveuger
Air pollution has a significant impact on student performance in the US. Each one-unit increase in particulate pollution reduces test scores by 0.02 standard deviations.

Among Americans 25–34, 41% of women and 50% of men were single in 2023, a share that has doubled over the past 5 decades. Between 2010 and 2022, the fraction of people living alone rose in 26 of the 30 OECD countries.
Gold is up 37% for the year, outperforming the “impressive, AI-fueled” S&P since the start of 2020. Central bank accumulation reached 1,000 tons for the third consecutive year.

Middle-income jobs in the US’s leading sectors are migrating out of high-cost cities. Headcount at securities dealers in New York fell 21% btw 2008 and 2024, film production fell 16% in LA, and tech manufacturing fell 32% in Silicon Valley.

Linking the decline in the share of US output devoted to goods rather than services to the twin budget and trade deficits, Warshawsky stresses the role of the budget deficit in financing the expansion of the low-productivity-growth healthcare sector.

Amazon has deployed more than one million robots in its facilities, which are at their lowest employee headcount since 2015. Since 2015, Amazon's productivity has improved from 175 packages shipped per employee annually to 3,870.
The New York Times reports that Amazon’s automation team expects the company can avoid hiring more than 160,000 workers it would otherwise need in the US by 2027 due to increased automation.

Kenneth Austin and @hillelnadler argue that tax and other preferences for foreigners holding U.S. assets are a driving force behind the large U.S. current account deficits and negative net asset positions, and recommend reducing their generosity.

.@JoachimVoth @LagakosDavid reviewed oral histories of 1,400 older Depression-era Americans on life satisfaction and found that work and community contributions are on par with family in living a meaningful life for both men and women.
US trade deficits driven by push factors like surplus savings from other countries, which drive capital into the US. @KennethAustin, Real World Economic Review.

Inker and Pease argue that 80% of the S&P’s outperformance relative to advanced economies since 2010 arose from two sources that are unlikely to repeat: dollar strengthening and near all-time high valuation ratios, which “always beggar future returns.”
43% of American adults say widespread betting on sports is "a bad thing for society," up from 34% in 2022. 47% of men under 30 say legal sports betting is bad for society, up from 22% in 2022.

A WSJ-NORC poll finds the % of Americans who say they have “a good chance of improving their standard of living” fell to 25%, a record low since 1987. The survey results are more negative than predicted by macro conditions, suggesting unmeasured fears.

25% of unemployed Americans have a college degree. Overall, degree holders had an unemployment rate of 2.8% in September, up 0.5pp y/y. 9.2% of all Americans 20–24 were unemployed in September, up 2.2pp y/y.
The Chinese government has started managing SMIC's chip output, prioritizing Huawei’s demand as American export controls have created an “acute” shortage of advanced semiconductors in China.

America remains a high-trust society, though Americans with fewer friends report lower trust levels. 79% of Americans with at least 6 friends say strangers would help them if their car broke down, relative to 58% of respondents with no friends.
States that had above average fertility rates in 2014 are responsible for 80% of the decline in American fertility over the last decade.

The concept of Import Certificates (ICs) aims to balance trade by issuing ICs to U.S. exporters equal to their export value, which they can sell to importers. This could make U.S. goods 10% more competitive internationally, boosting exports and job growth.

The West’s rare-earth industry is revving up as both private and government capital flow into the sector. MP Materials’ stock is up 354% year to date, and Lynas Rare Earths’ is up 186% relative to the S&P 500’s 15.5% return.

Why are constant-quality house prices 15% above their pre-2007 peak? Ed Glaeser notes that US housing grew just 0.6% annually in the 2010s, down from 4% in the 1950s. Sun Belt metros now mirror coastal markets: supply-constrained and high-priced.

Supply curves in four key sunbelt areas have become less elastic. “High prices in the suburban parts of these areas no longer stimulate much new building, possibly because the residents of these areas have made it difficult to permit new projects”.
The US foreign-born population reached 51.4mm, or 15.4% of the population in 2024, Nicholas Eberstad notes, surpassing the prior peak of 14.8% set in 1890.

The US prison population was 1.6mm in 2009 and fell to 1.2mm at the end of 2023 as criminals who were arrested during the crime wave that peaked in 1991 die or are released. Because younger generations are not as violent, the stock of prisoners is declining.

Smaller, less expensive industrial robots dubbed collaborative robots or "Cobots" are helping to automate manufacturing in small US factories. Chris Mims argues “the slow, fragile recovery of goods production wouldn’t be possible without them.”

The U.S. redistributes a larger fraction of national income to the bottom 50% than European countries, despite government spending accounting for a smaller share of national income (35% vs. 47% in Europe).

Prior to mass schooling in the US, @AlthoffLukas @ReichardtHugo find that the mother’s human capital accounted for 65% of the variance in the child’s human capital. School attendance weakened this link to 35%, boosting economic mobility.
Morgan Stanley shows AI-related cap-ex growth exceeds total non-residential fixed investment growth for the year. “In other words, capex in everything not related to AI has actually declined.”

Despite significantly higher returns for low-income housing in the US and two European countries, institutional investors shy away from the market, limiting investment and leaving poor tenants facing steeper rents. @damensven @SVNieuwerburgh
Biden tax proposals would raise $3.8tn from 2021 to 2030, primarily targeting high-income households. This plan would increase tax rates, leading to a 0.06% reduction in GDP over the next decade.

.@benbernanke and @ojblanchard1 find that pandemic-era inflation across ten countries was initially driven by transient price shocks, but as these effects receded, tight labor markets and wage inflation became more significant and persistent factors.

Research by @RolandFryer finds that black & Hispanic individuals are over 50% more likely to experience non-lethal force in police interactions, despite controlling for context & civilian behavior. No racial differences in officer-involved shootings.

Both the Social Security retirement and Medicare HI trust funds face insolvency in 7 years. Goldwein proposes an Employer Compensation Tax that would “generate enough revenue to close two-thirds of Social Security’s funding gap and half of Medicare’s.”
A randomized trial of an intensive learning camp for underperforming Danish students found no lasting effects on academic or non-cognitive skills.

CBO forecasts that the US population will increase by only 17mm over the next 25 years. Deaths will exceed births starting in 2031, after which point net population growth will be entirely driven by immigration.
Consolidation has largely taken place below levels that antitrust experts view as anticompetitive.
Apple will start purchasing rare-earth minerals from MP Materials, and along with MP Materials, will build a factory in Texas with neodymium magnet manufacturing lines tailored for Apple products.
The @BIS_org annual report notes that real wages have declined in 2022-23 by more than in past deflationary episodes, but tight labor markets could threaten the disinflation process.

A study of MA community college cohorts between 2005-16 estimates that degree attainment in STEM within 6 years rose for males in all racial categories, largely driven by an increase in male enrollment in STEM from 15.4% in 2005 to 24.6% in 2016.

Corporate payouts in the 2000s are significantly higher than in previous decades, driven by both higher earnings & payout rates. 38% of increase due to higher earnings, 62% due to higher payout rates. @KathleenKahle

The Shleifer model suggests financial crises are more predictable than traditionally believed, particularly when examining periods of rapid credit & asset price growth. The probability of a financial crisis within one year of entering the Red Zone is over 13%, compared to a 4% baseline.

The shift out of dollar assets has likely peaked, but inflows are unlikely to return to the 2017–2024 mean of 43% of cross-border equity flows. Relative bond flows based on proxy flows from mutual funds and ETFs have "substantially normalized."
Research productivity in the US has declined by a factor of 41 since the 1930s, averaging a 5% annual decrease. To sustain constant GDP growth, the US must double its research efforts every 13 years.

Angel investments in Norway from 2004-18 had highly skewed results: ⅓ were a total loss, the top 1% returned 50X invested capital, and the average investment returned 2X. Top angels tended to be connected to board members and founders before investing.
The Economist highlights research that suggests high-performing employees who switched to a new firm underperformed relative to colleagues who stayed put.

The “convenience yield” of US Treasuries, as measured by the yield of AAA corporates over government bonds, fell from a mean 67bps over 2012–19 to 36 bps in 2025, consistent with the increased relative supply of government debt raising financing costs.

The concept of an economic singularity is defined as the point where the economic growth rate surpasses 20% per year, driven by superintelligent computers that render human input economically superfluous.

Updating his chart showing a striking correlation between the Covid inflation and that of the mid-1970s, albeit at a lower level, Rangvid suggests that current upside risks to inflation might leave us with a second peak resembling that of 1978–1982.

Btw 2014 and 2018, firms with higher than median investment in AI experienced a large and statistically significant increase in systematic risk as measured by market beta, driven by upside risks “consistent with AI investments creating growth options.”

.@menaka_hampole et al. estimate that AI has little net effect on overall labor demand. Though “highly-exposed occupations experience relatively lower demand…the resulting increase in firm productivity increases employment across all occupations.”

Enrique Ide and Eduard Talamàs model the transition of AI from a “co-pilot” giving helpful advice to an autonomous “co-worker” generating useful output, and argue that autonomous AI will primarily benefit the most knowledgeable individuals.
AI likely won't substitute for labor, better thought of as capital deepening improving workers productivity.
AI can significantly impact the labor market by substituting capital for labor in tasks traditionally driven by human prediction, according to @AjayAgrawal.

Since January 2020, private sector real hourly earnings have fallen 9% in New York City, while increasing 3% nationally, as large firms based in NYC move jobs to lower-cost states. JP Morgan now has more workers in Texas than in New York.
Asia's foreign-exchange reserves have risen $400B this year to ~$8T. The increase has been in part driven by this year’s decline in the dollar and rally in gold prices.

Torsten Sløk argues the rise of passive investing (~60% of US equity funds) has led to reduced shorting, increasing market volatility, reducing liquidity, and rising P/E ratios for large-cap stocks like the "Magnificent Seven.”

Samples from the asteroid Bennu contain key components necessary for life, including all five nucleobases that make up DNA and RNA, and 14 of 20 amino acids found in proteins on Earth, suggesting life on Earth may have been "seeded" by asteroids.

.@SteveMiran @Nouriel argue that a rotation in Treasury's issuance policies from long-term debt to bills is the equivalent of a 100bps cut in the FFR and believe “activist Treasury issuance” is offsetting the Fed's efforts to slow the economy.

In the European Social Survey administered between 2002 and 2016, less-educated individuals were six times more likely to exhibit populist sentiment if policies of fiscal austerity were in place in the preceding electoral period than if they were not.

Australia, Japan, and the US agreed to increase “logistical interoperability” among their naval forces, including reloading missile systems, refueling at sea, repairing ships, and sharing data on maintenance.

“By enabling senior workers to accomplish more tasks independently, AI may inadvertently reduce entry-level opportunities, raising concerns about how future generations will acquire essential expertise” and potentially lowering growth in per capita GDP.
Automation technologies often reduce labor demand despite increasing productivity, as they displace workers with only modest productivity gains.

Between 1980-2016, automation targeted tasks where workers earned an average wage that was 35% higher than their next best job opportunity. Automation accounted for 52% of the increase in between-group US inequality over the period. @DAcemogluMIT

.@PikaGold notes countries with birth rates now below 1.3 saw “rapid growth in GDP per capita after a long period of stagnation or decline” as women’s new labor market opportunities demanded more than the traditional male role in child-rearing.

The rise in female college enrollment from 1930-80 hasn’t reduced marriage rates for college women. “The overall decline in marriage rates is driven almost entirely by a sharp drop in marriages between non-college women and non-college men.”

The 10-year French OATS spread over German bunds yields is nearing the highs sparked by last year’s political crises. France’s finance minister warned that the country may need an IMF bailout like that of the UK in 1976.

The US labor market is tight, with low unemployment and high vacancy rates. Historical data shows that a decrease in vacancy rates has always been accompanied by a significant rise in unemployment, challenging the Fed's hopes for a smooth adjustment.

A Bank of America analysis suggests Treasury's anticipated decision to issue more short-term bills may drive the 10-year yield lower by more than 25bps. That decision would likely result in bills accounting for 25% of outstanding debt, up from 20% today.

Data from 39 countries show that countries with low bankruptcy efficiency experience a 3 ppt decline in GDP following a 5-year business credit boom, while in high-efficiency countries GDP barely declines.

A fiscal package spearheaded by French premier Bayrou and intended to reduce the government's budget deficit from 5.8% of GDP to 4.6% will likely result in a no confidence vote. Socialists “cannot accept” cuts and freezes to welfare programs.
Men were nearly evenly split btw Trump and Biden in 2020, a shift from 2016 when Trump led men by 11 points.

Citing a Citi analysis, Greg Ip suggests that over the next several years, “AI could raise productivity growth by 0.5 to 1.5 percentage points a year—less than the ‘Internet Revolution of 1995–2000,’ except in the most bullish scenario.”

Between 2000 and 2024, NATO's defense spending averaged 1.72% of GDP, a cumulative $2T short of the 2% target, “funds that should have been invested…in force structure, modernization, and readiness but were instead deferred or cut.” @MEaglen

Immigrants, 9% of 2024 voters, slightly favored Harris over Trump (51% to 47%). In 2020, those voters favored Biden by 21pp. In 2020, Trump’s narrowly losing coalition was 86% white; 4 years later, Trump’s winning coalition was only 78% white.
China has threatened retaliation against proposed Mexican tariffs on Chinese imports. Cars made in China make up 20% of domestic Mexican car sales.

The Chinese government said the US spin-off of TikTok will still use ByteDance's algorithm. It remains unclear if ByteDance would retain control of the algorithm in the US under the proposed licensing agreement.
.@benbernanke and @ojblanchard1 argue that bringing the current inflationary episode to target implies an unemployment rate of 4.3%, up from 3.4% last month.

Setser argues the IMF is likely to underestimate China's 2025 BOP surplus. “The customs goods surplus increased by $150B in the first half of 2025, and a conservative forecast of the current account surplus through Q2 2025 puts it at just over $600B."
75% of rising btw-firm inequality is from rising inequality at industry level, primarily driven by inter-industry earnings differentials.
Crime fell in 2020, but the risk of street crime victimization in NYC, LA, and Chicago rose nearly 40% due to reduced public foot traffic.
Western European living standards are 67% of the US by income measure, but 85% when considering broader welfare metrics, according to @CharlesJones in the American Economic Review.

Manufacturing job losses have a larger impact on US fertility rates than unemployment rate fluctuations, making further reductions in unemployment unlikely to reverse declining fertility trends @NathanSeltzer Demography.

Credible central banks shouldn’t follow Taylor rules that prescribe a >1-for-1 response of the policy rate to inflation, but “should look through…inflation that is not expected to persist,” as the Fed did in its post-covid “immaculate disinflation.”
@JeffreyHAnderson in terms of non-fatal violent crimes, no statistically significant difference btw reported race of offenders by victims and percentage of arrestees by race.

Raising the federal minimum wage to $15 an hour could lift 1.3m Americans out of poverty but also lead to 1.3m job losses by 2025, according to the Congressional Budget Office. Impact varies by state, with rural areas facing more severe consequences.

The American Families Plan would add over $1tn to the national debt over the next decade, as proposed revenue measures fall short of covering its costs. 57% of married-couple households would receive federal benefits.
Big companies have been driving wage and job growth in America's smaller cities, acting as significant economic engines. Limiting their growth could reduce competition and stifle job creation.

Meta and Microsoft 2025 capex is approaching 40% of revenue. MS estimates there is a $1.5T gap btw the hyperscalers’ forecasted datacenter spending of $2.9T over the next three years and their ability to self-finance the spend.

A survey primed 9,013 Americans with information about American billionaires' earnings, tax rates, tax avoidance strategies, and lavish lifestyles. In all cases, the effects on preferred tax rates were far lower than expert predictions.

Enrico Moretti and @wilson_daniel_j find 35% of billionaires leave states that have an estate tax. However, for the average state the additional revenues from an estate tax exceed the loss of revenues from forgone income taxes by 31 percent.
The draft bipartisan infrastructure deal allocates less than 19% of its new spending to roads, bridges, and major projects, amounting to $110bn out of a total $579bn in new expenditures.
Bird flu is surging in part due to the fall migration, resulting in the deaths of almost 7mm farmed birds in the US since the start of September.
As firms have stayed private longer wealth creation has shifted from public to private markets. @mjmauboussin

Racial gaps in mobility are relatively small for those with median AFQT scores. The black-white gap in moving out of the bottom quintile is 5.2pp, compared to 27pp unconditional. @BhashkarMazumder, Economic Perspectives.

US advanced manufacturers import between 27% and 39% of their intermediate inputs and capital equipment. Jiaxin He and Connor O'Brien argue tariffs “are likely to backfire, raising costs for American factories and slowing reindustrialization."
Boeing is planning on building a clean-sheet design aircraft to succeed the 737 MAX. It would be the first new commercial aircraft for Boeing since 2007’s 787 Dreamliner.
Households accumulated $2.5 trillion in excess savings btw March 2020 and January 2022, driven by elevated disposable personal income and reduced consumer spending @WendyEdelberg

Traders are betting on 10-year yields falling from 4.3% to 4% in the coming weeks in light of Jerome Powell's recent statement that cuts would come "sooner rather than later" if inflation remains contained.
Bloomberg’s U.S. Aggregate Bond Index, largely comprised of Treasurys, investment-grade corporate debt, and agencies, has had a total return of ~6.7% since the start of year.

Since 2000, Domino’s Pizza has outperformed Google, Tractor Supply has outperformed Apple, and Old Dominion has outperformed Amazon. Torsten Sløk notes, “boring is often a better strategy than fancy.”

Between 2000–2019, an average of 83,000 western Europeans lost their lives every year as a result of extreme heat, compared with 20,000 North Americans. Yet due to climate concerns, air conditioning is frowned upon and restricted in the UK and Europe.

Variation in construction costs has had relatively low predictive power for variation in house prices, with increased decoupling over time suggesting “increasingly binding restrictions that prevent housing supply expansion in high-demand areas.”
Goldman forecasts an annualised total return of 6.5% for the S&P 500 over the next decade, underperforming STOXX Europe 600’s 7.1% (7.5% in $ terms) and Japan’s 8.2% (10.2–11.7% in $ terms).
Bloomberg estimates Microsoft, Alphabet, Amazon and Meta will spend $420B on capex next fiscal year; up from $360B this year.

The US Census Bureau’s survey of “likely employer” (HBA) business applications is a leading indicator of growth in total nonfarm employment and overall output. “Likely non-employer” (NHBA) applications predict self-employment activity. @JHaltiwanger_UM

Tax policy significantly influences business organization, with top earners increasingly deriving income from pass-through entities. In 2018, pass-through businesses accounted for 95% of all U.S. businesses, generating $1.3tn in income.

Purchases of Treasurys in 2025 have been “solid.” Foreign buyers bought a net $375B through July and Treasury’s adjustment of the duration mix by shifting towards bills and maturities in the belly of the curve (~2–10 years) has supported demand.

Wang worries that White House efforts to induce surplus countries to liquidate dollar reserves and invest in US industrial projects in exchange for lower tariffs may raise interest rates and cause those nations “to seek to diversify their dependency.”
Standard Discount Rates Imply $1 Of R&D Today On Average Creates At Least $10 Of Economy Wide Benefits.

As part of an effort to increase housing construction and lower housing costs, California rolled back the longstanding California Environmental Quality Act, which had been used to block new housing construction.

California’s share of US tech jobs is the lowest in a decade, falling from nearly 19% in late 2019 to just over 16% today. Californians maintain an advantage in high-end jobs, earning ~⅓ of the industry’s total compensation - above the 2019 level.

Increased LFP by older workers has nearly doubled, leading to a significant labor supply shock, suppressing wage growth & contributing to lower inflation, according to @BenoitMojon @Bank_for_International_Settlements.

German industrial production is only at its 2005 level, even after a partial rebound in September. Since the start of the year, Germany has run a deficit in capital goods with China, the first since 2008.

Price wars left 8 Chinese carmakers profitable in the first half of the year. A senior executive at BYD expects 80% of China’s 120 carmakers to be “pushed out” of the market as the government’s “involution” campaign takes hold.

Research by @ThomasBuser highlights competitiveness as a key predictor of educational & labor market outcomes, strongly correlated with higher education levels, prestigious college majors & superior occupational positions.

Research by @WilliamDow suggests economic policies like minimum wage & EITC have limited impact on reducing "deaths of despair", particularly drug-related mortality. They can reduce non-drug suicides but overall effect is modest.
Card et al, find that the 25-30 percentage point college enrollment gap between disadvantaged boys and girls with IQs of ~116 closed among students who qualified for a “gifted” program. @EricChyn

Market reaction to CBO scoring of legislative proposals on “large negative proposal days” implies the 10-year rises by 0.75 bps for a one-time 1 ppt increase in deficits/GDP, cumulating to 6.75 bps for a persistent deficit shock. @HannoLustig

Market reaction to CBO scoring of legislative proposals with large negative cash flow projections implies an estimated 57¢ of each dollar in major fiscal expansions is unbacked by future surpluses and passed through to Treasury valuations. @HannoLustig
Canada scrapped a digital services tax hours before it was to go into effect. After scrapping the tax, "Carney and Trump have agreed that they will resume negotiations."

In the 20% of occupations most exposed to AI, employment of 22- to 25-year-olds declined 6% since late 2022, driving this cohort’s “tepid overall job growth,” while employment in each of the >25 age groups rose between 6% and 8%.
The American corporate sector has been substantially self-financing since 2000. Net equity issuance is negative even after taking stock-based compensation expenses into consideration.

Capital expenditures net of depreciation for the Russell 3000 peaked at 6.9% of sales in 1988, but has since declined to 1.8% on average in the past decade, highlighting a shift in capital allocation strategies.
.@mjmauboussin shows capital expenditures net of depreciation as a percentage of sales peaked in 1988 at 6.9%. Over the past decade it has averaged 1.8% and fell to 0.5% in 2020 during the pandemic.

Healthcare capital intensity plays a crucial role in policy analysis, influencing productivity measures & rates of return. Robust capital data is needed to inform strategic decisions in the healthcare sector, impacting economic growth & efficiency.

Contrary to Piketty and Saez’s recent claim, new @nberpub research by Matt Smith @dannyyagan @omzidar and Eric Zwick provides persuasive evidence that a majority of top 1% and 0.1% income is labor income—chiefly business owners.
Car seat laws have led to 145,000 fewer births since 1980, with 90% of this decline occurring since 2000.

A 14-year study of 20mm Italian workers finds that family-owned firms have ~ 16% lower wages than non-family-owned firms, not due to differential productivity or amenities. Fewer promotions in family firms suggest efforts to maintain family control.
AI investments have not translated into sustained TFP growth post-financial crisis, despite significant unmeasured investment in AI-related intangible assets. @CarolCorrado

@MikeGonzalezNY @NewYorkPost The ideological shift in teacher education has significant economic implications, prioritizing political indoctrination over academic excellence, ultimately impacting workforce readiness & productivity.

At the end of 2024, US public companies had a cash-to-assets ratio of 9%, well above the long-term mean of 7.5% over 1970-2024. The driver of the increase in cash holdings appears to be the growth in intangible, relative to tangible, assets.

Home Equity Cash Outs At Highest Level Since Crisis @OrlaMcCaffrey @WSJ U.S. homeowners extracted $152.7bn in home equity through cash-out refinancings in 2020, a 42% increase from 2019 and the highest level since 2007, according to Freddie Mac.

Total returns for catastrophe bonds have risen 14% y/y and 50% over the past five years, according to a Swiss Re’s index. Bondholders haven’t experienced significant losses despite insurer payouts running >$100B/year since 2020.

Over 2008-2020 residential segregation along party lines rose at all geographic levels. Increased concentrations of Democrats were driven by the rise of new, younger voters, and of Republicans by established voters’ switching to the GOP. @VinPons

The CBO released an updated cost estimate for the OBBBA projecting that the bill would add over $2.4T to primary deficits over 10 years and increase debt from 100% of GDP to 124% by 2034, 133% if interest rates remain high.

@JamesCapretta 30mm Americans under 65 were uninsured in 2019, 20m eligible for subsidized coverage but unenrolled, 9.8mm ineligible for subsidies. Addressing gaps is crucial for near-universal coverage, as highlighted by the CBO's analysis.

Using CBO scoring, the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget calculates the Senate’s version of the reconciliation bill would add over $3.9 trillion to the national debt by 2034 including ~ $690B in cumulative interest costs.
CBO projects a decline in overall labor force participation rate by 2.7pp, reaching 60.1% by 2028, primarily due to aging population.

Kiley and Miskin argue that curbing threats to financial stability is essential to price and economic stability, but that pursuit of additional objectives like climate change and inequality is not feasible for monetary policy.
CEOs report that nearly 80% of innovation projects fail to succeed, highlighting challenges in implementing emerging technologies & fostering innovation.
The U.S. productivity slowdown since 2004 has resulted in a $2.7tn gap, with mismeasurement not accounting for this shortfall.

US Census data show that btw 2005 and 2023, the fraction of Americans aged 25–34 who completed their education rose from 74% to 83%, but the % “ever married” fell from 62% to 44%, and the % with “a child in the household” fell from 55% to 39%.

Enrollment in teaching colleges instead of increasingly valued research universities and moves out of computer science and engineering led students with parental incomes in the bottom ⅓ to now "earn less than ½ the enrollment wage premium" of the top ⅓.
Btw 2016 and 2019, median family income rose 5% while mean income decreased 3%, indicating a narrowing income distribution. Real median net worth increased 18% and mean net worth rose 2%.

.@krogoff @YaredPierre @hafrouzi argue that strengthened central bank independence and more credible public debt policies are required to offset inflationary pressures from trade-distorting geopolitical tensions and rising government deficits.

Raj Chetty @OppInsights finds that a white child born into the bottom household income quintile in 1992 had a 29.7% chance of remaining there, up from 24.9% in 1978, and an 11.9% chance of rising to the top quintile, down from 13.7% in 1978.

.@michaelbauer_hh @CarolinPflueger and Adi Sunderam find that after the March ‘22 “liftoff,” Fed policy became increasingly sensitive to inflation surprises and that public perception of this “regime change” improved the Fed’s inflation-output tradeoff.

Children who grew up in counties with higher employment rates had more economic mobility than peers raised in counties with lower rates, even if their parents weren’t employed, suggesting a relationship mediated by social interaction. @OppInsights

Since the 1996 welfare reform, child poverty has significantly decreased, with children now half as likely to live below the official poverty threshold. Deep child poverty has dropped from 2.4% to under 1%, particularly among single-parent families.

Bonney et al show that in Norwegian data there is a large “child penalty” for female, but not male, entrepreneurs. “Female-owned businesses experience a substantial decline in profits, steadily decreasing to 30% below baseline ten years post-childbirth.”

Highly educated women are increasingly balancing career and family life, with childlessness rates declining and family sizes growing. By 2014, 22% of women aged 40-44 with a master's degree or higher were childless, down from 30% in 1994.
Children of immigrants exhibit higher upward mobility than native-born counterparts, regardless of country of origin, according to data. @EmilyBadger

Chinese regulators have banned domestic firms from further purchases of Nvidia’s RTX Pro 6000D chip, the chip Nvidia produced expressly for China, as Beijing pressures Chinese tech companies to replace Western imports with domestic technology.

CPI readings suggest that deflation is taking hold in China. Reduced demand for Chinese goods due to US tariffs, Brooks argues, requires looser Chinese monetary policy and devaluation of the yuan; China’s refusal is an implicit acceptance of deflation.

China is limiting rare earths export volumes to prevent foreign stockpiling of rare earths and downstream products such as magnets used in electric motors. Chinese exports of rare earths are down 38% y/y.

CCP officials have attacked "neijuan" or “involution,” meaning low-priced, disorderly price competition. Overcapacity, driven by industrial investment, is fueling, and potentially entrenching, deflation.

The US and China have agreed to de-escalate the trade war, with China delaying implementation of new export controls on rare earths for a year in exchange for the US postponing expansion of additional American export controls on chips.

Chinese exports hit $1.8T through 2Q2025, driving a record surplus of $586B. Bloomberg notes: "The pickup in China’s export growth in June was led by a rebound in shipments to the US after a temporary thaw in the trade war. The blip may not last long."
Bloomberg estimates that China's trade surplus will reach a record $1.2T in 2025, ~ 20% above its 2024 surplus of just under ~$1T.
China has reduced its reliance on the dollar with the CNY's share of global trade finance transactions increasing from 1.9% btw 2018–2021, to 6.4% in November of last year, and 7.4% in March.

Chinese concerns over Nvidia’s H20 chips are not new. Chris Miller notes, “Beijing no doubt has always suspected that US-designed chips have deliberate back doors,” which had long motivated their drive for chip self-sufficiency.

While China is planning on easing exports of rare earths, a "validated end-user" system will keep them out of the American defense supply chain going forward, meaning the US defense industrial base will have to build an alternative supply chain.
China's manufacturing boom is cannibalizing European exports. The EU's trade deficit with China is set to double between 2020 and 2025 in euro terms.
More than 80,000 parts that are used in Defense Department weapons systems are made with critical minerals now subject to Chinese export controls, according to data from defense software firm Govini.

Chinese state television is broadcasting a new historical drama promoting “unification” of China and Taiwan, and “state-owned drama troupes are receiving approval only for war-themed plays...while other genres are being rejected.”

China is planning to retaliate against Mexican tariffs on Chinese automotive exports. The effort is one of the highest-profile actions by Beijing to deter third countries from working with the US to enact barriers to Chinese trade.
China produces 70–80% of commercial drones and accounted for 79% of approved drone patents globally in 2024.

China has launched a crackdown on content that incites “excessively pessimistic sentiment,” such as “defeatist” ideas like “hard work is useless” in the Chinese system or questioning the value of marriage.
China is responding to American chip export restrictions by undertaking a massive expansion of domestic chip manufacturing, attempting to triple the country’s current output by the end of 2026.
At the CCP’s recent plenum, only 168 of the 205 Central Committee members attended; 26 of the absences lacked explanation, suggesting Xi’s anti-corruption purges are wider than publicly known.

China has sanctioned South Korean shipbuilder Hanwha for allegedly cooperating with new American fees on Chinese vessels sailing to US ports. Hanwha recently purchased the Philadelphia Shipyard and has secured work on American naval vessels in Korea.

In the face of widening losses, China has ordered the solar sector to rein in overcapacity. China controls ~90% of the world’s solar cell manufacturing capacity; that capacity has outpaced current global demand.

28% of China's car manufacturers and 31% of electrical machinery builders are losing money, up from 12% and 16% in 2011, respectively, yet Chinese investment in manufacturing is rising by 7.5% this year, following a 9.5% increase in 2024.
Chinese regulators have mobilized to dissuade China’s tech companies from acquiring Nvidia’s H20 chip. As a result, domestic tech groups are holding off or downsizing their H20 orders.

New Chinese export controls will allow it to manage exports of foreign-manufactured magnets that contain trace amounts (.1%) of Chinese-sourced rare earths, or were produced using Chinese IP. China controls 93% of magnet manufacturing.
On the heels of the Trump administration’s reversal of the US export controls on H20 chip exports, Beijing is urging domestic firms to avoid purchases of Nvidia H20 chips.

In exchange for a trade deal, China wants American export controls on high-bandwidth memory (HBM) chips, key components for AI chips, relaxed. The chips would allow Huawei to manufacture AI chips that are more competitive with Nvidia’s.

China's goods exports to the US are down 22% y/y but have been offset by a 12% increase in goods exports to the rest of the world. Robin Brooks notes that transshipping or selling outside the US will compress exporters' margins, both acting as deflationary shocks.

Tsinghua students and faculty are creating more patents related to machine learning and AI than MIT, Stanford, Princeton and Harvard combined. However, American patents, as measured by citations, are rising in relevance compared to Tsinghua’s.

China’s persistently weak consumer spending since Covid, now 17% below the pre-pandemic trend, has led to an entirely export-led recovery of Chinese manufacturing, with flat imports creating negative spillovers for the rest of the world, Klein argues.

In an effort to shore up automotive supply chains, the Chinese government mandated a 60-day supplier payment rule. Most car makers suffer negative working capital; only a handful of Chinese EV makers have sufficient net cash to comply with the new rule.

China's economy, despite growth, isn't overtaking the U.S. due to inefficiencies & rising costs. China's high production costs, welfare burdens & debt (over 300% of GDP) hinder growth, while the U.S. benefits from higher productivity & innovation.
About ~200mm Chinese “flexible workers” without formal contracts account for ~25% of the overall workforce and 40% of the urban workforce.

China's surplus in manufactured goods is now over 2% of global GDP; greater than the combined surpluses of Germany and Japan at their peaks. China's overall goods surplus is $1.2T, $800B higher than it was in 2020.

Setser notes that “in the last few years, the onshore yuan almost never trades ‘strong’.” He suggests that China’s de facto FX policy is to limit appreciation pressure by treating the Central Parity Rate (the “fix”) more as an upper limit than a target.

To increase China's fertility rate of 1, Beijing is planning a child subsidy of $500 a year for the first three years of a child’s life. The number of newborns will likely drop to <9mm this year, less than 50% of the 2016 level.

Royalty payments to Chinese firms as a percentage of GDP still trail other advanced economies, though Chinese royalty payments are growing faster than other countries’ in recent years. Royalty payments to China from ROW rose 5-fold btw 2015–2022.

China consumes 16mm barrels of oil a day, 75% of which is imported. Since February, China has stockpiled 110mm barrels, bringing its stock to 1.2B barrels. 1.5B barrels would cover 140–150 days of imports. China is also stockpiling industrial metals.

Official gold purchases by China's central bank are so low that "few in the market believe the official figures." Société Générale estimates that China's total purchases of gold this year could be 250 tonnes or 1/3 of global central bank demand.

Brad Setser argues that China’s BoP surplus, which now ~ equals Europe’s, misrepresents its true surplus. China masks exports through foreign subsidiaries and investments, as evidenced by its customs surplus growth.

China's precisely targeted rare earth export controls were "probably the key factor in forcing Washington to reverse its tariff rises on the country." The American auto industry would effectively shut down if the controls were not lifted. @crmiller1
China’s youth unemployment (16–24) rose to 17.8% in July. 12.2mm college students will graduate this summer and enter the labor force.

China’s youth unemployment (16–24) rose to 18.9% in August, its highest level since the measure was adjusted in 2023. The unemployment rate for workers 25–29 also increased to 7.2% in August, up from 6.9% in July.

Chinese exports dropped for the first time since "Liberation Day." The 1.1% y/y fall was due to a 25% decline in exports to the US. China is still on track for a record trade surplus, hitting $965B so far this year.
Between 2020 and 2024, enrollments in China’s kindergartens (ages 3 to 5) declined from 48mm to 36mm, a 25% decline.
Americans residing in metropolitan areas with populations exceeding 1m are over 50% more productive than those in smaller cities, even when accounting for education, experience, industry, and IQ.
The American manufacturing trade deficit in 2024 was $1.2T. Robert Lawrence estimates that closing it would increase the share of manufacturing employment from 7.9% to 9.7% an increase of 1.7pp.
Startups within 20 meters of each other in a US tech co-working hub experienced significant knowledge spillovers, with proximity effect diminishing rapidly beyond 20 meters.
Music training cognitive benefits debunked: Meta-analysis (n=6,984, 254 studies) shows zero effect size. Perceived gains (g=0.200) stem from study design flaws, not actual cognitive enhancement.

High Cognitive Reflection Test (CRT) scores are linked to distinct decision-making patterns in men and women, with significant economic implications. Women with high CRT scores exhibit increased patience, while men with high CRT scores demonstrate increased risk-taking behavior.

Data from a British birth cohort followed since 1958 show that cognitive skills early in life predict wages at age 50 better than cognitive skills at age 50. Early cognitive skills likely allow for higher educational attainment or on-the-job learning.

Analysis by Gerald Auten and David Splinter challenges the prevailing narrative of a dramatic rise in US income inequality, suggesting "relatively little change since 1960" in the income share of the top 1%.

Data from public universities in Texas show students whose test scores marginally qualify for their target 4-year state college have higher educational attainment and eventually earn 10% more than counterparts whose scores marginally fail to qualify.

College graduates' wages have remained flat this century after adjusting for inflation, while college costs have soared, making the payoff not universal & varying based on individual circumstances & economic conditions.

.@OppInsights finds that the “Ivy-Plus” (Ivy League, plus UChicago, Duke, MIT, Stanford) admit students from the highest income families scoring in the top 1% of SAT/ACT at far greater rates than those from lower-income families.

The Yale Budget Lab projects that the combination of OBBBA and the tariffs in place as of June 1 results in a net income reduction of ~1% for the median household, a 6.5% reduction for the bottom 10% of households, and a 1.5% increase for the top 10%.
After adjustments detailed below, Splinter finds that the Forbes 400’s effective tax rate is above that of the full population by 13pp, contrary to BSYZ.
.@john_iselin @danhreck propose an alternative estimate of unreported income and find that pre-tax income share of the top 1% rose by 0.52pp from 1962-2014. (labeled in the chart as “PSZ Macro.")

@JasonFurman Despite low levels of public investment in transportation infrastructure, the U.S. has not experienced significantly worse macroeconomic outcomes. Infrastructure spending as a share of GDP has remained stable at 2.4% over the past decade.
@DavidSplinter Working Paper: Auten and Splinter argue that Zucman's methodology overestimates tax evasion by approximately $460bn.
Adjusting for changes in how housing inflation is measured reveals that achieving target inflation today requires disinflation similar to the Volcker era.

.@ikuziemko et al. find that less-educated US voters have consistently favored “predistribution” policies such as protectionism and strong labor unions, while more-educated Democratic elites have reduced support for “predistribution” since the 1970s.

Btw 1988 and 2023, the US IT sector’s TFP rose by 178%, while TFP in all the non-IT sectors combined rose by only 12%. Taking account of sectoral linkages, the IT sector contributed ~17pp to TFP growth since 1988, and the non-IT sectors about 20pp.

Forbes data on billionaires from 57 countries over 1986-2011 show that a 1 standard deviation in founders' aggregate wealth/GDP yields a 1.87 ppt rise in TFP growth over the next 7 yrs, vs. 1.28-ppt lower TFP growth for a 1 standard deviation rise in billionaire heirs' wealth/GDP. Via Jim Pethokoukis.
Product market concentration has been decreasing since 1994, with highly concentrated industries dropping from 44.4% in 1994 to 36.6% in 2019.

Measuring concentration accurately requires establishment-level data, reflecting the size distribution of all firms, not just large or publicly traded ones. The Hirschman Herfindahl Index (HHI) is preferred for its detailed insight into revenue distribution.
Workplace-occupation wage sorting drives inequality: 1999-2017 correlation doubles, explains 67% of wage gap growth. Key trend: High/low-wage jobs increasingly cluster in corresponding workplaces.

Jan Hatzius argues that "China’s trading partners are unlikely to tolerate sustained further expansion in the goods trade surplus, which already stands at 0.8% of global GDP." Trade restrictions may drive deflation in China.

Jiang, et al. find that despite a shortened maturity structure, fiscal expansion over the last 2 decades has reduced the convenience yields of US Treasuries, which are now negative at the long end, undermining the “reserve currency status” of the dollar.
New evidence suggests corporate excess profit share is likely 10-20%. @JenniferGravelle, Government Accountability Office.

The 2005 U.S. corporate tax cut, particularly the Domestic Production Activities Deduction (DPAD), significantly impacted wage distribution. A 1% cut in marginal tax rates increased average earnings by 1.1%, with small firms seeing higher gains at the top of the earnings distribution.

.@YannCoatanlem and @olivercoste find that restructuring costs in the EU are 10x that of the US and argue that “the cost of failure is a first-order factor of Europe’s lag in tech, with major consequences for its competitiveness and standard of living.”

Data on 38mm Italian and German workers in 3.7mm firms show that a large supply of older workers amidst slow growth has limited career progression for younger workers and led to an increasing wage gap between older and younger workers. @MatteoParadisi

At 65%, the US homeownership rate is 4pp under the 2004 peak but on par with its 1995 level. Sunderji argues that as credit expansion "reaches its limits, the prospects for maintaining even current ownership rates are growing increasingly uncertain."

@menzie_chinn and @hiroitopdx find that banking crises, currency crises and debt crises all move the current accounts of emerging market economies toward surplus, typically due to reductions in investment.

Mark Warshawsky and Giorgi Bokhua @AEIecon estimate that the US has a sustainable gross debt limit of 154% of GDP, “which is only 30 percentage points above the current level, projected to be reached by 2034.”

Worker churn from low to high productivity firms decreases during recessions, impacting overall productivity dynamics. @HenryHyatt highlights the complex interplay btw economic cycles and worker reallocation.

Q2 and "Liberation Day" saw the dollar's share of official foreign exchange reserves drop from 58% to 56% with the Euro's share rising from 20% to 21%. The decline in the dollar’s share of Central Bank reserves in Q2 was due to dollar depreciation rather than reserve managers pulling out of the dollar around “Liberation Day.”

Firms using data to forecast future demand leads to increased markups, according to a new model by @JanEeckhout. Data-rich firms invest more, reduce costs, and shift production towards high-demand, high-markup goods, boosting economic efficiency.

Citing reports from the Atlanta and Kansas City Feds of data center construction “causing a step increase in regional electricity loads.” Kedrosky suggests that power is the biggest constraint on continued datacenter capex at the current rate.

Paul Kedrosky notes that, since August, GPU rental rates in the US have declined 4%. He writes that a flood of liquidity from a robust securitization market has driven “a flywheel of data center development disconnected from true demand.”
US productivity growth has slowed since 2004, with adjustments to IT-related hardware, software, and services showing only modest improvements in GDP and investment figures. @DavidByrne

The return of lower-paid workers who left the labor force during Covid as well as other workers’ willingness to accept lower pay for work-from-home jobs left average real wages in Q1 ‘24 down 3.5 to 4.4 ppts relative to 2006-19 trends.

Gold as a share of world central bank reserves increased from ~12% to ~17% btw 2000–2024. Weiss argues this is part of “diversification not solely aimed at the dollar share" and there has been little erosion of the dollar’s role in invoicing and trade.

AI diffusion through "knowledge-based" service sector jobs has increased - and will likely continue to increase - demand for noncognitive “social skills,” with workers who have both cognitive and social skills faring the best.
A recent study challenges the notion that opioid addiction is primarily driven by economic despair, suggesting instead that the epidemic is more closely linked to changes in the drug environment.

Resumption of student loan payments resulted in an estimated annualized cutback in spending of $2,980 for the mean borrower, reducing consumer spending in the first quarter of 2024 by $20 billion, roughly 0.3% of GDP.

The net capital share of aggregate income in developed economies has risen since 1948, driven entirely by the housing sector, contradicting theories of capital accumulation @MatthewRognlie BrookingsPapers.

The net capital share in large developed economies has followed a U-shaped trajectory postwar, driven mainly by the housing sector. Initially declining until the mid-1970s, the net capital share has since moderately increased, contrasting with gross capital shares.

Rognile's analysis of 7 large developed economies shows only housing has a long-term increase in capital's share of income. Net capital income is low due to rapid obsolescence & returns aligned with labor, not capitalists @MatthewRognlie BrookingsPapers.

Applying a sector-by-sector analysis of Census Bureau survey data, Paul Kedrosky finds that AI adoption is sharply increasing in sectors outside of construction and manufacturing and is advancing in companies of all sizes.
Increase In "The Burden Of Knowledge" Btw 1997-2017 Likely Driving The -38% Decline In Potential High Impact Startups Headed By PhDs In Science And Engineering.
Top firms' surge in self-developed software stocks since 2000 is linked to lower displacement rates, creating a "natural oligopoly" & reducing turnover. @JamesBessen

Industry concentration increases are linked to declines in labor share, as capital share doesn't compensate for the reduction in labor share. Profits rise instead, offsetting declines in both labor & capital shares.

.@jean_twenge and David Blanchflower cite 11 studies confirming a decline in life satisfaction particularly among the unmarried young. “The U-shape in wellbeing by age that used to exist…is now gone, replaced by a crisis in wellbeing among the young.”

US Treasury rates exceed “secured, extra-safe yields for synthetic bonds” computed from market swaps by 51 bps at a 10-year horizon and 84 bps at 30-years, possibly indicating “default to 10-year and 30-year horizons at about 10% and 50%, respectively.”

The bulk of the decline in the gender gap among full-time college educated workers born btw the 1931 and 1984 birth cohorts is within occupation. Changes in fields of study contribute on net only ~5.5pp out of a more than 40pp drop.

Between 1975 and 2015, an increasingly inelastic supply of specialized talent encouraged incumbents to “overhire to deter entrant innovation.” A pro-innovation policy would tax incumbents and subsidize entrants. Jesús Fernández-Villaverde @AEIecon

Producer prices for durable consumer goods had fallen 3.9% y/y in China as of September. Brooks argues that, given the importance of exports to the Chinese, American tariffs are helping to entrench deflation in China.

.@yfatihkarahan et al argue that 52% of the decline in US start-ups since the late 1970s is explained by a drop in labor supply growth linked to demographics. The findings are supported by cross-state startup and labor supply growth data.
Two-thirds of the decline in US startup rate since 1979 is attributed to the slowdown in US labor supply growth, according to @NYFed @Aysegul_Sahin @BenjaminPugsley @FatihKarahan.
No “Great Demographic Reversal”: population aging will likely continue to push down r through 2100.

Auclert, et al claim to refute the "great demographic reversal" hypothesis, finding that aging in the developed world will “increase wealth-to-GDP ratios [W/Y], lower asset returns [r], and widen global imbalances [NFA/GDP] through the twenty-first century.”

Aging population projected to impact global economic balances, leading to a 63bps decline in US real interest rate. Demographic shift increases US wealth-to-GDP ratio by 35%pts, with Japan & India seeing 85%pts & 310%pts rises, respectively.

Btw 2010 and 2030, an estimated 734m jobs are needed globally to address demographic shifts & achieve target unemployment rates. 91% of these jobs must be created in low/middle-income countries, where demographic changes pose a larger challenge.
CEO demographics shift: Avg exit age rises to 64 in 2022 from 62 in 2010. Tenure lengthens to 9.7yrs from 8.4yrs. Both metrics signal extended leadership spans.
Nicholas Eberstadt warns that depopulation will stress families as smaller families "become ever less able to bear weight—even as the demands that might be placed on them steadily rise."

The Center for American Progress estimates that there are 446,000 undocumented construction workers in the US, more than a fifth of the total. Deporting them would cause “increased housing costs, reduced housing supply, [and] construction delays."

Jaremski and Schuster document that before the establishment of the FDIC, deposits fled to the safety of local insured postal banks, illustrating that lack of universal deposit coverage amplifies run risk. @ssprickschuster

.@christopherruhm examines adverse mortality trends for prime-age non-Hispanic Whites from 1999-2019 and finds that “worsening mental health is not the predominant explanation,” contrary to the Case and Deaton “deaths of despair” narrative.

The 2024 rise in CA’s minimum wage in fast food restaurants from $16 to $20 raised the sector’s wages ~8% and lowered its employment by 2 to 4% relative to the US sector overall, with an estimated loss of 18,000 CA fast food jobs. @jeffreypclemens
Early termination of pandemic-related UI benefits in 18 states in June 2021 led to a 14pp increase in unemployed workers getting a job, but also increased financial stress. @GlennHubbard

PPP lending reveals small banks exceed historical share while $250bn+ banks reduce average loan size. Operational differences explain some variation, risk management likely drives large bank restraint.

In a study of over 80 US manufacturing industries from 1870-1909 @cmicmeissner concludes that higher tariff rates reduced labor productivity. “The era’s high tariffs are unlikely to have helped the US become a globally competitive manufacturer.”

The COVID-19 pandemic doubled monthly net out-migration from large cities to 56k/month in 2020, compared to 28k in 2017-2018, led by fewer new arrivals rather than more departures. Higher-income renters saw a 210% jump in net outflow, while major metros with over 5m residents were most affected.

.@kearney_melissa finds higher fertility in states with greater FHA/VHA loan issuance among women aged <= 20 when FHA loans began in 1935. She argues FHA/VHA led to 3mm births over 1935-1957, 10% of the baby boom's rebound from low interwar birth rates.

John Burn-Murdoch argues Guenther’s "representation gap" theory is “visible in the US,” where the mean voter’s preferences on immigration are “far more conservative than those of Democratic party elites," and closer to those of Republican politicians.
The "genius share" of US labor income surged from 6.7% in 1984 to 31.4% in 2006, highlighting income concentration among exceptional talents. @SethGBenzell

Digital capital, comprising IT-related intangibles, is concentrated in superstar firms, predicting productivity. Its contribution to growth is double that of IT capital stock, with a 3-year lag btw investment & realized gains.

Joe Wang believes a small reduction in federal spending, along with tariffs and the resumption of student loan payments, suggest that fiscal policy will not be as supportive of growth as it was in 2023–2024.

The US spent just under $1T in the 12 months ending in June on “recovering from or preparing for disasters,” according to a Bloomberg analysis. During the 1990s, the annual average was only $80B in current dollars.

.@KurmannAndre and team find that the relative generosity of CARES Act unemployment insurance programs “held back the aggregate employment recovery by 4.7 percentage points between April and December 2020.”

@XJaravel finds inflation rates differ by income quintiles. Accounting for inflation inequality reduces 1983-2019 real income growth for the bottom quintile from 12.5% to 2.1%, and from 19.1% to 12.0% for the next, with little change at the top.

National market concentration has risen, but local concentration has declined, particularly in services, retail trade, and FIRE sectors, according to @EstebanRossiHansberg @FederalReserveBankOfRichmond.

The 2023 OECD Survey of Adult Skills reveals the US has ~ 3 low-scorers for every high-scorer. Germany has nearly 3X as many high-scorers per low-scorer as the US; Scandinavia has more than 5X and Japan more than 7X.

In contrast to the 19th century, when trade deficits increased US investment, Pettis argues, in the 21st century, trade deficits “cause the debt to rise, [the share of] productive sectors like manufacturing to decline, [and] income inequality to rise.”
New studies increasingly report less growth-enhancing effects of corporate tax cuts, with recent findings suggesting a negligible impact when controlling for other tax types & budgetary components.

.@JADHazell and @sj_hobler review inflation swap market reactions to the results of ‘21 Georgia Senate run-offs which allowed Democrats to pass legislation on a party-line vote. They infer that the resultant stimulus caused ~30% of 2021-22 inflation.

Historical analysis reveals that fiscal deficits often lead to inflation, particularly during wartime. Record-breaking deficits in the post-pandemic era raise the risk of sustained money growth fueling excess demand & fiscal dominance over monetary policy.

Austria's extensive family policy reforms over 60 years have not narrowed the gender pay gap. The raw gender gap in earnings remains roughly 40% despite a 30 percentage point decrease from 1953 to 2017.
European investors held 29% of non-conforming high-risk MBS not backed by USG in 2006. 2/3 of CP issued had European sponsors, with 57% of dollar-denominated CP having European backing.

Research by @MichaelQMcShane at @AEI finds weak correlation btw test score improvements & long-term life outcomes, challenging policy focus on test scores as primary metrics for evaluating educational programs.

Reviewing the impact of minimum wage increases on employment over 2009 - 2019, @NeumarkEcon finds strong negative employment effects on low-skilled black workers and little impact on low-skilled white workers.

.@andy_garin notes that WWII-era government plants boosted earnings for disadvantaged workers, but “million-dollar plant” policies in the 1980s failed to lift wages, highlighting limits of approaches that lack upskilling of “left-behind” workers.
Idaho’s Return to Work Bonus of up to $1,500 was associated with a 0.4pp decrease in the unemployment rate and a 2.4% increase in nonfarm payroll employment. @MichaelRStrain
According to @HendrikBessembinder, 5 firms account for 10% of wealth creation btw 1926-2016, while 4% of firms account for all net stock market gains over the period.

Analysis of 1.2m U.S. inventors reveals that the top 1% earn over 22% of total inventors' income, with high correlation btw income and social impact. Reducing top income tax rates has limited potential to boost aggregate innovation, as it primarily influences those already exposed to innovation.
Wealthier individuals tend to consume less & save more, driven by bequest motives & heterogeneity. APC decreases from 0.09 for bottom 20% to 0.01 for top 20% of resource quintiles.
Btw 1993 and 2008, median earnings for graduates from very selective schools increased by 4%, while those from less selective schools rose by 7%.

A study analyzing data from 30 European countries reveals that individual downward social mobility does not directly correlate with increased hostility towards immigrants, but macro environments with high downward mobility & low upward mobility rates do foster more negative attitudes.

US jobs programs, transfers, and macroeconomic upturns tend to reduce property crime but not serious violent crime, so these programs have little impact on the total social costs of crime, which are driven by serious violence.
Education spending effectiveness confirmed: 92% of multi-state studies (12/13) show significant positive outcome correlation. Meta-analysis validates causal link btw funding and student achievement.

Import competition from China drove +12% rise in nationalist party votes across EU (1988-2007). US regions with high automation job loss showed +8% Trump support in 2016. Areas with -5% house price drops saw +15% populist vote share in UK/FR elections

A field experiment reveals that workplace competition boosts labor supply, with men working longer than women in high-prize tournaments. In a competitive scheme offering a $30 bonus, 55% of workers completed the full 40 minutes, increasing work time by over 80%.
A J.P. Morgan analysis notes that taken at face value, the $160B in DOGE savings would be only 2.3% of projected 2026 spending prior to the Reconciliation Bill.

A broad dollar trade-weighted index has depreciated by ~ 7% this year, and Goldman argues it remains 14% overvalued on a trade-weighted basis, as macroeconomic policies make it harder for the US to attract unhedged capital flows.
