Investors are still very long dollar assets, even though some are starting to hedge or modestly reduce their exposure. Joseph Wang argues the dollar may have “much more to fall” if fiscal deficits are not reduced and a dovish Fed chair is appointed.

The dollar fell 3.4% btw April 4th and the 14th despite a 50 bps rise in the yield spread btw the 10-year Treasury and the 10-year Bund. Relative to historical behavior, this implies a flight from private dollar assets, not merely Treasuries.

The US is freezing new export controls on China as trade negotiations continue. The US may allow exports of Nvidia’s H20 after direct lobbying from Nvidia’s CEO though no exports have been approved formally.
"Encounters" by Border Patrol agents on the southwest land border are at the lowest level in decades and "almost no one is travelling north through the Darién Gap."

Other than China and Canada, America's trading partners have largely avoided retaliation against US tariffs, allowing Trump to raise almost $50B in excess customs revenues without a significant impact on US exports.

Before 1996, high-funded industries had a 17% higher median q than low-funded ones, indicating better growth opportunities. Post-1996, this trend reversed; high-funded industries had a 15% lower median q than low-funded ones.

Employment of college graduates in AI-intensive and non-intensive sectors both grew 5% on net btw the rollout of ChatGPT in Nov. 2022 and the most recent data. Unemployment is up in computer science, but down in a number of other AI-exposed majors.

Adjusting earnings with the relatively standard PCEPI deflator, Winship finds that real earnings of year-round male workers aged 15+ were flat from 1973–79, but grew 13% from 1989–2023. With his experimental MACPI deflator, they grew 40% over 1973–2023.
Revised estimates suggest the U.S. Treasury loses only one-third of previously estimated revenue to BEPS due to double counting in accounting practices.

George Borjas finds that a 1981 French program giving legal status to undocumented workers who represented about 1% of all workers resulted in increased employment and wages for low-skill native and immigrant men and raised GDP 1%.

Btw 1985 and 2024, the median drawdown for 6,500 US stocks was 85%, with a duration of 2.5 years from peak to trough, and another 2.5 years to recovery. More than one-half of all stocks never recover to their prior highs. @mjmauboussin

Slow growth and aging account for ~½ of the ~3pp drop in the US natural rate R* between 1970 and the mid-2010s and “global spillovers” for ⅓. R* is now up 50+bps from the mid-2010s, “partly reflecting extraordinary fiscal stimulus.”

From 2013-2019, drivers in the taxi/rideshare industry grew six-fold to 1.3mm. The mean entrant in 2016 had net earnings of just $2,110, as the share of drivers supplementing other wage and salary earnings rose from <20% in 2011 to over 70% in 2015.
China's DJI can manufacture millions of drones a year; about 500 American drone manufacturers are collectively building fewer than 100,000 drones annually.
A $1 increase in the minimum wage is associated with a 1.4% share of low-wage job postings that require a high school degree.
The Dutch government is suspending its intervention in Nexperia following talks with the Chinese government. The Chinese CEO will not return to the job and the firm will be run by Europeans.

The Dutch government has taken control of chipmaker Nexperia over American and Dutch concerns that the firm was unable to act independently of its Chinese parent company Wingtech, which acquired Nexperia in 2019.

“Dynamic scoring” of budget proposals has both costs and benefits. “For some areas, the budgetary impacts of the currently excluded effects have been estimated to be significantly different from the impacts of the included effects.” @heidilwilliams_

Hamid Noghanibehambari and @jasonmfletcher find that children whose fathers lost their jobs in textiles and did not migrate during the decline of the New England textile industry in the 1920s and 1930s experienced “a 4-year loss of life expectancy.”

High frequency data show that many US workers - especially lower-income, hourly workers - face month-to-month, hours-induced, and within-firm pay fluctuations. Contrary to the Permanent Income Hypothesis, this affects consumption stability and utility.
The euro's 14% appreciation against the dollar since the start of the year may start to weigh on exports if the euro moves above $1.20, and may also cause inflation to fall below the 2% target.

Loans from the Bundesbank and other north European central banks prevented a sudden stop in southern Europe during the Euro Crisis. Now the same TARGET2 balances are growing as the French fiscal situation deteriorates, reducing pressure on French yields.
US firms see 6% wage decline & 5pp labor share drop 5yrs after appointing business manager, with no productivity or employment growth. Return on assets rises by 3pp, benefiting shareholders.

Medical Innovation That Could Accelerate End Of National US Shutdown By One Workday Is Worth Almost $30 Billion. Cumulative Costs Likley Just Over $8,000 Per Household, 1T Aggregate As Of April 26 @CaseyMulligan
Mobility among men has remained stable over decades, with 53% of sons born 1982-84 earning more than their fathers, similar to 51% of sons born 1949-51.
Americans have a higher likelihood of surpassing their parents' income, yet they face challenges in moving beyond their parents' income distribution rank.

Government size has a significant negative impact on growth, reducing private consumption & output per worker. Analysis of 108 countries from 1970-2008 shows government consumption consistently hinders output growth.

US infrastructure projects are expensive, with average costs reaching $1,601m per mile, compared to a global average of $478m. Complex designs, regulatory delays, and high labor costs contribute to these high costs. @EdwardGlaeser
The "China Shock" hardened existing racial and religious views among whites, rather than altering attitudes broadly. @MichaelStrain, American Enterprise Institute.
American’s top policy priority is “strengthening economy” 75%, followed by reducing health care costs and defending against terrorism 60%.

Workers 22–27 with at least a college degree contributed 7 bps, or 12%, of the 60 bp rise in the US unemployment rate since mid-2023, 2x their weight in the labor force. Math and computer jobs for this group fell 8% since 2022.

Research by @KevinLang and @MichaelManove finds that labor market discrimination drives lower black wages, not just premarket characteristics. Adjusting AFQT scores for education reveals significant wage differentials btw blacks and whites.

In Danish data, assortative mating on “ambition types” proxied by the wage paths attached to detailed educational programs rose ~20% over 1980-2018. Sorting on educational ambition rather than level explains >40% of the rise in HH inequality since 1980.

Effort has emerged as a key driver of US income inequality from 1980 to 2016, with data showing a stark contrast in income trends based on education and work hours. High school graduates experienced a significant decline in real earnings, while individuals with advanced degrees who work over 40 hours weekly saw substantial income gains.
.@jasonfurman argues that stabilizing the debt by 2034 will require $2-11T of fiscal consolidation over the next ten years, or 0.7-4.6% of GDP.

.@IEA expects US electricity demand growth of 2% annually from 2025-2027, up from a prior 1% forecast, largely driven by data centers. Currently, data centers consume 4% of US electricity and could reach between 6.7-12% of total demand by 2028.

Computing accounted for 8% of commercial sector electricity consumption in 2024 and is projected to more than double to 20% by 2050. More electricity could be consumed by computing than for any other end use in the commercial sector.

Carol Shiue and Wolfgang Keller find that descendants of elites that lost status after the fall of the Ming Dynasty in 1644 regained elite status in subsequent generations by achievement in civil service exams, “the ultimate gateway to power.”

.@RobertJShiller and @WGoetzmann find that subjective assessments consistently overestimate the risk of stock market collapse, and that emotional response to non-fundamental shocks explains at least some of the variation.

The 2021 Child Tax Credit (CTC) expansion increased government benefits to low-income families but reduced employment only among mothers with relatively low levels of education. @dwschanz @MichaelRStrain
Federal EITC expansion increases employment, expansion drove a 3.2-3.7% increase in employment among low-skilled unmarried mothers, federal and state expansion drove 2.9-3.3% gain.
Work hours increase with income inequality, with greater inequality predicting longer work hours, according to @SamuelBowles and @YongjinPark in The Economic Journal.

.@leah_boustan @Osea82 find Polish church-centered ethnic enclaves established from 1900-30 in the US hindered immigrants’ economic mobility, with an estimated “7% decline in earnings associated with a 10pp increase in own-ethnicity population share.”
8,800 miles of natural gas pipeline are planned or under construction in the US; over the next five years, ~$50B will be spent on pipeline construction.
Individuals Who Work With 1 Standard Deviation Higher Share Of Entrepreneurial Coworkers are 2.5pp More Likely To Become Entrepreneurs, An 8% Increase Relative To Mean.
Corporate R&D investment increases entrepreneurial spawning by 18.7% with a one standard deviation rise in R&D, according to @SabrinaTHowell. However, these spillovers do not harm the parent company.
The US and Israel led with venture capital investments exceeding 0.4% of GDP in 2018, while many European nations reported figures below 0.1%.

.@PeteKlenow and Huiyu Li argue that rising labor productivity raises the entry costs for new firms through higher wages and start-up costs, limiting the impact of productivity-enhancing policies on welfare.
The S&P 500 has seen a significant increase in intangible assets, reaching $21tn by 2018, more than double the amount in 2005.

Research by @XiangZhou suggests that higher education's impact on mobility is driven by selection effects, not equalization. Intergenerational income mobility among college graduates is similar to non-graduates once adjusted for selection processes.

Achievement gaps are wider in school districts with diversity officers. In districts without CDOs, the average black student is 1.9 grade levels behind the average white student, whereas in districts with CDOs, this gap increases to 2.4 grade levels.

After years of near-zero yields, 10-year Bund yields are trading around 2.5% down from March's 2.9%. The Bund market is "normalizing" with bond yields moving above interest rate swaps of the same duration.
.@AswathDamodaran estimates the current equity risk premium for the S&P 500 at 4.23%, the lowest level since 2008; the expected return on stocks is 8.6%.

The real natural rate of interest (r*) has been negative since 2009, according to @FederalReserve research by @ManuelGonzalezA and @JeanPhilippeLaforte. Model estimates show r* at -1% since 2016, decreasing to -1.7% by 2020.
US Department of Energy's SBIR program shows significant R&D spillovers: every patent by grant recipients leads to 3 more by other inventors, 60% of which occur within the US.

A 1% per year rise in a city’s manufacturing TFP in revenue terms between 1980-1990 boosted annual earnings growth by 1.5% per year over 1980-2000. Renters' purchasing power grew by 0.6%/year, and homeowners' by 1.6%/year.
The EU is planning on hiking tariffs on steel imports to 50%, matching the US's current rate. The bloc is hoping to negotiate a lower rate with the US while fending off cheap Chinese imports.

Deutsche Bank notes that the German economy has grown 1% since 2017 relative to US growth of 19%. Since 2000, the US share of global market capitalization has held steady at 48% while the EU/UK shares fell from 18% to 10%, and 8.3% to 2.6%, respectively.

.@MacrostrategyP argues that the EU has “traded growth for ideology” with “renewable electricity price 5x that of conventional electricity.” In March 2024 German businesses’ electricity prices were 1.7x prices in the US and 2.8x in China.

Goldman believes it is likely the French government will lose next week’s confidence vote, slowing fiscal consolidation. They foresee the French “deficit edging down from 5.4% this year to 5.2% of GDP in 2026.”

There has been a 21% drop y/y in illegal immigration into the EU so far this year. The EU’s border control strategy of paying countries like Tunisia and Egypt to control illegal immigration may be paying off.
Europe now has 3 drone manufacturers with “unicorn” status as venture capital investment in the defense sector surges in both the US and Europe.

Le Pen's National Rally is campaigning on rolling back recent rises in the retirement age, despite a 5.4% deficit and rising yields, in an example of how right-leaning parties across Europe are embracing leftist economic policies.
US efforts to reduce domestic pharmaceutical prices, without corresponding increases in other high-income countries, “could dramatically reduce firms’ investment in highly welfare-improving R&D.”
The recent rise in a dissimilarity index of the occupational mix between college graduates aged 20 to 24 and those aged 25 to 34 suggests a possible impact of AI on early career workers.
Including taxes + transfers LBJ's Poverty Rate has fallen from 19.5% in 1963 to 2.3% in 2017.
Financial aid has largely offset the rise in sticker prices of colleges, but hasn't kept pace with the rise in non-tuition costs. @JasonDelisle
California evidence suggests $1 increase in minimum wage reduces impacted workers' welfare by at least $1,590 annual, 11.6% of workers' annual compensation.

A “one size fits all” model of executive pay has become more common since 2006. This highlights the unintended consequences of the SEC’s rules for standardized pay disclosure in ‘06 and Say on Pay in ‘11, coupled with institutional investors’ influence.

Autor finds automation of a given routine task can “replace experts in some occupations and augment expertise in others.” Data from 1980–2014 show that occupations in which automation increased expertise requirements saw falling employment but rising wages.

Bengali et al. find the stagnation in the college wage premium since 2005 “is largely due to demand-side changes: a slowdown in the pace of skill-biased technological change and rising substitutability between college and high school educated workers.”

Interest rate parity suggests the USD is undervalued by 9.5%, Torsten Sløk finds, but a richer model points to much milder undervaluation. Noting renewed interest in US assets, he expects the dollar to appreciate as the trade war fades.

China's PISA test-takers reportedly outscored the mean Western test taker in math and science by over 100 points. However, 85% of the population, and a higher share of students, reside in regions for which Beijing does not disclose PISA scores.
Germany, known as the "Exportweltmeister", faces anemic returns on its overseas investments, ranking last among G7 nations from 1950 to 2017.

A cross-country statistical study provides robust evidence that expropriation risk such as corruption negatively impacts innovation by reducing productivity-enhancing activities including R&D. @NBERpubs
Education-inequality link weakens: College premium explains 75% of wage gaps 1980-2000, drops to 38% 2000-17. 10% college supply increase reduces wage premium 6%, within-group gaps dominate.
The euro area, particularly Germany and the Netherlands, is the largest contributor to global imbalances, with higher-than-warranted current account surpluses.
Nvidia’s 8% weight in the S&P 500 is the largest of any individual stock since the start of the data in 1981. Nvidia has a P/E ratio of 58.

Firms that benefited from the corporate tax cuts in the 2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act responded with increased investment relative to firms that were not impacted, according to @gchodorowreich @omzidar Eric Zwick and Matthew Smith.

Creanza presents evidence that the Great Merger Wave (GMW) of 1895–1904 had a large causal effect on innovation, driven by corporate R&D labs and increased “breakthroughs" (novel and impactful patents) in science-based fields by 30% btw 1905 and 1940.
A study covering most US commercial banks from 1865 - 2023 finds that 80% of pre-FDIC bank failures resulted from “rising asset losses” and “deteriorating solvency,” not mere bank runs.

Capital spending by the tech sector drove 35–45% of US GDP growth over the past three quarters. Without this capex, Mike Cembalest notes, “US growth might already have converged to ~1% due to weakness in consumption.”

Low interest rates may explain the rise of superstar firms, which benefit disproportionately. In 1980, the spread was 31bps; by the 2010s, it grew to 127bps due to lower borrowing costs relative to “following” firms.

Analysis of the Forbes 400 reveals a shift in wealth origins over recent decades. Fewer individuals in this elite group have inherited their wealth or grown up wealthy compared to the 1980s and 1990s.

FCI*, a measure of policy neutrality, accounts for financial conditions overall. Post GFC, FCI-FCI* suggests far greater tightness than the FFR. In mid-2022, reflecting mortgage rates, the FCI-FCI* tightens even relative to the higher FFR.

Citing the rise in the 30-year yield as the market prices in more rate cuts, Brooks argues “If the administration wants low interest rates, it should work on narrowing the deficit…not bullying the Fed into rate cuts.”
Analysis shows 2/3 of household debt reduction is due to write-offs, not active repayment. Banks' actions drove debt reduction, not consumer behavior. @KarenDynan @NYFed
Global population projected to peak at 9.73bn in 2064, US population to peak at 336m in 2062, driven by declining TFR & aging population @EmilyGoren

Noting the benefits of deregulation and permits for new infrastructure will take time to materialize, Michael Cembalest argues "When/if 12%-15% correction levels are hit on the S&P 500, I would look at deploying some of a portfolio’s excess liquidity."

Shleifer et al find that “return spreads typically attributed to exotic risk factors are explained by predictable movements in non-rational expectations of firms’ earnings growth,” excessively bullish for growth stocks and bearish for value stocks.

Financial crises often result from a combination of the crisis itself & pre-existing imbalances in credit & asset prices. Credit-to-GDP ratios often exceed 150% & asset prices can inflate beyond historical norms, creating bubbles that are vulnerable to bursts.
16% of Trump voters previously supported Obama, highlighting a shift in voter allegiance. 50% of Trump voters support deportation policies, while 20% identify as liberals or moderates.

Kevin Hassett @Jon_Hartley_ @joshrauh estimate that following the 2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, a 1pp drop in the cost of capital raised the investment rate in 2022 by 2.33 pp relative to 2016, 3x the CBO’s 0.7 pp estimate.
Research finds 2/3 of the rise in earnings inequality is attributed to increased variance in average earnings btw firms.

Public company managers’ conference call comments about their cost of capital vary widely from its actual cost; 80% of the variance suggests managerial error. Those who perceive higher capital cost invest less, reducing TFP by 5%. @NielsGormsen

Between 2004–2024, an average of 2.1mm people annually became first-time home buyers. Last year there were only 1.1mm first-time buyers, relative to 1.9mm in 2008; 46mm American households are renting, a record high.
.@cwcalomiris argues high American public debt levels and chronic deficits may lead toward an era of "fiscal dominance," in which the government forces banks to hold non-interest-bearing debt.

.@ernietedeschi analyzes Trump's proposed tariffs, both with and without retaliation, and projects $1.2-$4.4T in revenue over 10 years, a 0.5-1.4% decline in real GDP, and a $1.9-7.6k decline in average real disposable income per household.

The IMF projects that global public debt levels will approach 100% of global GDP by 2030, up from ~65% in 2007, primarily driven by the US and China. They argue that “much larger fiscal adjustments than currently planned are required to stabilize debt.”

.@MA_Bolhuis notes that over the last 60 years, monetary R* was significantly below “fiscal R*”, the rate required to stabilize debt as a % of GDP, but that a narrowing gap requires growth-enhancing reforms and fiscal consolidation to avoid inflation.

Robin Brooks argues that prior to the pandemic, US debt service was “manageable” even as debt soared, as older, higher-coupon debt was rolled over into lower-coupon debt. That dynamic has now reversed.
Countries with lower debt ratios pursue more expansionary fiscal policies, resulting in milder downturns post-crisis. @ChristinaRomer
"Labor productivity in U.S. construction in 2023 was essentially the same as it was in 1948." Btw 1970 and 2020, labor productivity in the American construction sector fell more than 30%.

Since September, hyperscalers have issued ~$90B of investment-grade debt at higher yields than expected. Post-issue prices of some of the bonds have declined. The cost of CDS’s on Oracle’s debt have climbed.
Btw 2010 and 2023, direct property damage from flooding totaled $144B (in 2023 $). The National Flood Insurance Program covered 35% of the direct damages.

@MichaelCembalest VC returns have consistently outperformed public equity markets, with outperforming S&P 500 median firms returning 1.1x and average firms 1.4x, a 0.3% gap btw mean and median results.
Top earners are more likely to become entrepreneurs when labor market opportunities decline in top consulting, finance, and technology firms.

If US business investment is not “saving-constrained,” Michael Pettis argues, “the American economy will not adjust to net foreign inflows with higher domestic investment, and therefore it must adjust with lower domestic saving.”

Central banks are not responding to dollar weakness as they historically have. Though Bloomberg's Spot Dollar Index is down ~8% since the start of 2025, Treasuries held by official entries at the New York Federal Reserve have fallen $48B since March.

Federal Reserve research finds that an increase in foreign economic policy uncertainty is associated with excess US stock returns over the following 6-12 months. These excess returns are attributable to news about cash flows rather than discount rates.
On a rolling one-year basis, foreign inflows into American assets hit a record high in June, driven by equity inflows, which offset directionally weaker foreign demand for Treasury notes and bonds.
Foreign investors in US Treasuries outperform domestic investors on a risk-adjusted basis, with private foreign investors achieving higher Sharpe ratios.
Hedged investment into US bonds and equities overtook unhedged holdings according to a Deutsche Bank analysis, as international investors seek to manage potential further depreciation of the dollar.

The dollar rally observed in 2008 was driven by repatriation of US money overseas, partly from unwinding carry trades, not inflows from foreign investors, Setser argues. “Investors should not assume that the dollar will rally in future instability.”

With its debt at only 30% of GDP, Denmark is attracting foreign investors, who owned ~ 25% of Danish debt in 2019, compared to almost 45% today. Overall, Brooks argues, “global investors are retrenching at home.”
Foreign holdings of Treasuries at $9.01T held close to a record high in April, down just $36B from March. Private selling accounted for all of the decline; official entities were net buyers.
Education plays a crucial role in labor earnings, with a 4-year college education yielding a 52% earnings premium, or 13% per year, according to @DavidDeming @nberpubs.
Paul Kedrosky notes that the flare-up around OpenAI's proposed debt backstop suggests “how fragile the capital structure behind this compute-intensive ecosystem has become.”

Goldman estimates overall American power demand is accelerating to a 2.5% CAGR (a growth rate not seen since the 1990s), ~ 40% of which is driven by datacenters. They estimate that 60% of the new generation capacity will be sourced from natural gas.

Since 1970, cumulative real income growth for pensioners in France and the UK has outpaced that of the workers who support them. French pensioners over the age of 65 have higher incomes than working-age adults.

Brooks blames the fact that “high debt countries run bigger budget deficits than low debt ones” on moral hazard created by the ECB. “If there’s no risk of a debt crisis, why bother with arduous reforms that will get you booted out of office?”

As expected, French Prime Minister François Bayrou lost a no-confidence vote this Monday on his proposed budget-cutting measures. French 10-year yields, at 3.47%, are now above those of Greece, and closing in on Italy's 3.51%.
French Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu resigned less than a month after his appointment, damaging the ability of France to confront a 5.4% of GDP budget deficit. French 10-year yields rose to 3.57%.
GS data show that at least 10 French firms are trading at a negative spread to the French sovereign. “Sovereign borrowing costs typically act as a baseline for yields on corporate bonds.”
Negotiations over changes to Macron’s 2023 retirement reform that raised the minimum retirement age to 64 from 62 have seemingly deadlocked, which could potentially trigger a no-confidence vote.

Newly reappointed Sébastien Lecornu has proposed suspending plans to raise the retirement age to 64 until 2027. In exchange, he wants other spending cuts and tax increases that would stabilize the deficit at <5% of GDP.
By 2037, 67% of US counties will have fewer prime age adults (ages 25-54) than in 1997, despite adding 24.1m prime working age adults & 98.8m people overall.
US labor force growth, driven by birth rates 16 years prior, is linked to increased concentration, slower new firm entry, and declining labor share.

Evidence from France suggests public research spending spills over to the private sector; firms in the top 25% of exposure to academic funding increase their R&D effort by 20% relative to firms with the lowest exposure.
Citing the AI-related equity boom, crypto and the rise of sports betting, Greg Ip argues that "speculation has become woven into today’s political, economic and cultural psyche.”

Germany’s historic rearmament marks an industrial shift for a country that has lost ~250,000 manufacturing jobs since the onset of the pandemic, adding at least 16,500 jobs in the defense sector since 2022, with at least 12,000 more planned by 2026.
European populations experienced significant evolutionary changes after the Neolithic period, notably an increase in height and intelligence scores, as evidenced by genome-wide polygenic scores.

From 1945-46, the US unemployment rate grew by 3pp despite a 24% decline in GDP, supported by a 10% shrinkage of the total labor force (largely women and GI bill students) and pent-up demand for consumer durables and residential/business investment.

Robin Brooks amends his earlier analysis to note that the decline in the dollar's share of Central Bank reserves in Q2 was due to dollar depreciation rather than reserve managers pulling out of the dollar around “Liberation Day.”
Immigration's wage impact is often skewed by selection bias, particularly in France. Adjusting for bias reveals similar wage elasticity for men and women (-0.8 to -1.0).
A 1SD increase in parental environment quality boosts IQ by ~2.83 points, highlighting the economic benefits of investing in family environments. @MattMcGue

Study (n=3000): High polygenic scores boost advanced math placement + persistence. Top 2% score students still underenroll in highest math. SES advantaged schools 2x better at supporting both high/low score students.

US firms hit by controls restricting exports to China saw negative stock returns that wiped out $130 billion in market capitalization and drops in bank lending, profitability, and employment. @mcrosign @linahan56358916 @andrefjsilva

Citing Fervo’s 70% y/y reduction in drilling times, a Stanford analysis suggests “the power costs of geothermal will be competitive with rival fuels by 2027.” A Princeton analysis suggests geothermal output could triple US nuclear power by 2050.

As Germany remilitarizes, @GeneralTheorist forecasts German gross debt will rise from 64% of GDP last year to 76% of GDP in 2029, increasing the available supply of Bunds by ~5% of German GDP over the next two years.
Analysis reveals that when adjusting for dwellings & self-employed workers, labor share has remained stable since the 1970s in advanced economies, excluding the US. @GermánGutiérrez.

Germany's elevated savings rate, at 11% of disposable income, has left households poorer due to low investment returns & negative interest rates. German median household wealth is €61,000, lower than Greece's. @TomFairless

Germany and Italy, which hold the largest gold reserves after the US, are facing domestic pressure to repatriate the 1/3 of their respective reserves currently stored in the US, with a combined value of ~$245B.

Despite Japan's external assets increasing 13% y/y to $3.7T in 2024, an all-time high, Germany assumed Japan’s position as the largest creditor nation due to its current account surplus of ~€250B and the euro's appreciation.

A comparison of German and Swiss bond yields suggests the dramatic extent to which Germany has suffered a loss of both its safe haven status and its prestige, as its ability to confront its fiscal deterioration and that of its neighbors has declined.

Friedrich Merz is backing a series of protectionist measures to insulate the country's steel industry from cheap Chinese steel, including tariffs and a tax on imports from countries “that do not apply the same CO₂ emissions standards as the EU.”

A data-driven method to select cost-effective policy interventions, applied to survey responses of ~1,000 people reared in poverty in 3 US cities, confirms the primacy of education, but finds an ~= role for childhood determinants of noncognitive skills.
Firms in the top quartile of growth by sector outpace peers in intangible investments, with top growers investing 2.6 times more than low growers. @EricHazan
H-1B visa access drives startup success: +1 std-dev in lottery wins boosts funding probability +4.3pts (+10% from baseline). Data confirms skilled immigration's impact on entrepreneurial outcomes
Renters with net worth < $300,000 are 2x as likely to report that “always giving my best effort at work” is “not important” than either renters with > $300,000 or homeowners.

The key drivers of elevated European long yields are higher inflation and chronic fiscal deficits, but another catalyst may be lower demand for long-dated debt, as the $2T Dutch pension system transitions from a defined benefit to a defined contribution system.
Amid a global sell-off of long bonds, the 30-year Treasury yield hit 5% until disappointing data on US job openings caused it to retreat to 4.9%, and Japan’s 30-year yield briefly hit a record high.

House prices in US zip codes with high foreign-born Chinese populations grew 8% more after 2011, driven by Chinese capital inflows, but this trend reversed with the U.S.-China trade war. @CaitlinGorback @BenjaminKeys, @nberpub.

Over the next two years, the US must refinance debt exceeding 25% of GDP at sharply higher rates. Treasuries issued in 2024 carried an average yield approximately 2 percentage points higher than debt maturing in 2025-27.

.@GoldmanSachs forecasts that by 2075 both India and China will have slightly larger GDP than the US, but US real per capita GDP will rise from $69k in 2021 to $132k, vs. 2075 forecasts of $55k for China and $31k for India.
According to an IMF analysis, global imbalances grew in 2025 but are poised to narrow as the unwinding of pull-forward behavior associated with the implementation of tariffs dissipates.

FDI flows into China have decreased, while flows into other emerging markets remain steady. Robin Brooks suggests "China’s status as an export hub for the world looks increasingly challenged over the medium term."
Capital inflows can depress domestic demand by affecting exchange rates, leading to zero-sum beggar-thy-neighbor devaluations & currency wars at the Zero Lower Bound (ZLB).

Global current account imbalances rose in 2024. China’s surplus was up $161B. The US current account deficit widened by $228B, and the euro area surplus rose $198B, fueled by higher public saving in the euro area and dissaving in the United States.
US science and technology clusters show higher productivity per capita compared to Asian and European counterparts, according to the Global Innovation Index 2020 @WorldIPOrganization Orion Penner.

Since Russia’s 2022 invasion of Ukraine, China, unlike other emerging markets, has seen muted capital inflows. Robin Brooks argues this suggests investors are “putting a greater weight on geopolitical risk in the case of China.”
The S&P 500 has outperformed US private equity buyouts over the past decade, according to @BainAndCompany 2020 report.

High-skilled migrants are moving from diverse countries to a select few, notably the US, UK, Canada, and Australia. In 2010, these 4 countries attracted nearly 70% of high-skilled migrants to the OECD.

U.S. real total capex reached an all-time high in Q1 2021, driven by hard & intangible capex. Core capital goods orders have shown consistent growth, with nondefense orders increasing in 13 of the last 15 months.
Banks adjust geographic lending distances in response to credit conditions, expanding during expansions & contracting during downturns, according to @JoaoGranja @nberpubss research.
Gold fell by as much as 6.3% (5.2% as of now) today after hitting a record high on Monday. Year-to-date, gold has risen 55%.

Gold accounted for 20% of global official reserves in 2024, outstripping the euro’s 16%, and second only to the US dollar at 46%. The price has risen 27% this year to an historic nominal high of $3,500/troy ounce.

Gold prices hit a record high of $3,508.70/troy ounce; prices have doubled since the beginning of 2023. Last year, gold became the world’s second-most common central bank reserve asset after the dollar.

Gold’s spot price has risen 50% since the start of the year. Since Powell’s Jackson speech, gold has risen 18% while the dollar has remained stable against G10 currencies in a broad debasement of advanced economies’ currencies relative to gold.

Gold has surpassed its real peak in 1980, hitting an all-time, inflation-adjusted high of $3,674.27 per Troy ounce. When gold hit $850 nominal in January 1980 (~ $3,590 in 2025 dollars), the US was grappling with a collapsing currency and stagflation.
The age of peak earnings, or "golden age," has remained stable at 45-50 years old in the U.S. over the past 30 years, but decreased from 55 to 33 years old in China.

Since January, gold is up 42.4%, experiencing its strongest rally since 1979. John Authers argues the rally “seems to be driven by rational calculations of central banks,” suggesting it’s sustainable.

The value of foreign central banks' gold holdings, currently $3.83T, will likely soon eclipse the value of their Treasury holdings, now $3.92. Gold has already overtaken the euro as central banks’ second-largest asset.

11/20 sub-categories of core goods have likely reacted to tariffs, with an overall impact of 50% pass-through to consumption goods. Virtually all tariff increases for household appliances have been passed on whereas the prices of new cars have not risen.
Engineering teams at IBM and Google both believe they are on track to build industrial-scale quantum computers by the end of the decade.
Google claims it successfully ran an algorithm on “Willow,” its quantum computing chip. The breakthrough “clears a path for useful applications of quantum technology within five years.”
Low interest rates are not mysterious but result from higher savings, lower growth, and increased market power, according to @GregMankiw.

.@HannoLustig and @rgomezcram argue the pandemic was a period of “fiscal dominance” in which bondholders insulated taxpayers from increased spending by absorbing capital losses. From March 2020 to March 2022, the government’s real debt fell by 10%.

Gust and Skaperdas find that when people form expectations of future debt over a cognitively realistic 5 yr horizon, a permanent 1 ppt increase in debt-to-GDP raises the term premium on the 10-year by only 3 bps, half of the perfect foresight estimate.

U.S. patents relying on federal funding plateaued at 30% in 2011 and is currently around 28%. The absolute number of patents dependent on federally supported research nearly doubled from 22,647 in 2008 to 45,220 in 2017.

US industries have become more concentrated over the past 4 decades. Data shows increased industry concentration correlates positively with productivity & real output growth, while remaining uncorrelated with price changes & overall payroll.
According to @WilliamRKerr @nberpubs 55% of productivity growth stems from expansion into new niches, while 20% comes from shop floor improvements & 20% from new firm creation.
Research by @RichardTownsend finds CEO pay has increased due to firms granting consistent stock options, whose value has risen with firm equity returns, averaging 30% annually during the Tech Boom.

The CBO's dynamic analysis of the reconciliation bill forecasts an increase in the deficit of $2.8T over 2025–2034; increased borrowing raises interest rates on the 10-year by a mean of 14bps and real GDP increases by .5% over that period.
Analysis of private equity fund performance reveals a divergence in persistence btw buyout & venture capital funds. @RobertHarris @TimJenkinson @StevenKaplan @RuedigerStucke, @nberpubs
The correlation btw firms' employment and market capitalization has significantly declined since 1973, indicating a growing disconnect btw the stock market and the broader economy.
Surveys suggest a 4.6% decline in desired hours worked during pandemic, double the decline in LFPR.

Approaching the Trump administration’s self-imposed 90-day deadline for trade deals, Torsten Sløk posits that extending the deadline by one year would leave trade partners "happy" with 10% and Trump with $400B of annual revenue.

In a study of 1,299 candidates for CEO positions from 2000 to 2019, @KaplAnalysis compared pre- vs. post-2009 results, and found that, “interpersonal or ‘softer’ skills do not increase over time, either for CEO candidates or hired CEOs.”
R&D spillovers remain unchanged from the 1980s through the 2010s, with $4 of social benefit for every $1 of R&D spent. @BrianLucking

According to an FT analysis, time spent on social media globally has declined 10% since its 2022 peak. An exception is North America, where in 2024 users spent 15% more time on social media than Europeans.

Over the past 10 years, $9T has been spent globally on electrification, however Michael Cembalest points out that renewables' share of final energy consumption is still advancing at only 0.3-0.6% per year.

Tariffs implemented during the 2018-2019 trade war were “at best a wash, and may have been mildly negative” in terms of employment, but increased political support for Trump in the 2020 election. @davidautor

List and Uchida find that the “fade-out effect” of early childhood education programs “is critically-linked to the share of classroom peers assigned to preschool access—with enough treated peers the classic fade-out effect is muted.” @Econ_4_Everyone @haruka__uchida
Norwegian tax data reveals significant heterogeneity in individual returns to wealth, with a 180 basis point difference in median returns btw the 10th and 90th wealth percentiles.
Research on Danish manufacturing firms reveals that offshoring to low-wage countries leads to significant shifts in domestic employment composition, with a rise in tech and research-related roles.

The share of US firms with growth over 130%/year declined from 18% in 1985 to 12% in 2015, driven by a decline in new firm formation and slower growth among existing firms. @ngoldschlag @JHaltiwanger_UM @jdanielkim
Btw 2014-2016, the top 100 high-income nonfilers failed to pay nearly $10bn in taxes, highlighting a significant oversight by the IRS.
High-income households fail to report 21% of their income, with 6% attributed to undetected strategies. Offshore accounts & pass-through businesses drive underreporting. @RichardRubin @WSJ
High school sports participation reveals no consistent evidence of positive spillovers on wages, LFP, or college attendance, challenging the notion that sports foster beneficial skills
US health care spending rose 5.8% to $3.2tn in 2015, driven by the Affordable Care Act's coverage expansion. Spending per person was $9,990. @CMSGov.

Btw 2019 and 2023, automation helped China increase its export share in labor-intensive sectors. During that period, Chinese manufacturers added ~280,000 industrial robots every year, 50% of the global total.

In a sample of ~140k homeless people, Meyer et al found that 40-50% aged 25-59 had earnings of $12-14k in 2018 dollars and 80%+ had benefits from SSI and related programs. For those with low permanent income, even modest events trigger homelessness.

Given subsequent price appreciation and the “stability of homeownership post-1960,” purchasing a home btw 1940 and 1960 was an entree into the middle class that renters in the bottom income-tercile in 1955 largely missed out on.

Kedrosky estimates capex related to the datacenter buildout is ~20% of the railroad buildout in the 1880s and rising, though he cautions AI datacenter depreciation is high: “we aren’t building century-long infrastructure…datacenters are short-lived.”
Paul Kedrosky estimates that AI capex drove 20 to 40% of US GDP growth of 3% per annum in Q2, noting "for practical purposes (AI capex) ate Q2 GDP growth."

Richard Rogerson and team infer 20% of the inequality in lifetime earnings among American men can be explained by differences in hours worked, and that 90% of the difference in hours worked is explained by worker preferences.
Relative to median household income, home prices are 3% under the bubble peak and ~9% below the recent peak. Measures of home prices relative to income remain elevated.
US households showed limited balance sheet adjustments after the Great Recession, with debt reduction due to less new borrowing rather than increased repayment.
UK data shows changes in debt-to-income ratios had a bigger impact on household consumption than absolute debt levels, rejecting the debt-overhang hypothesis.
Median annual household income reached $63,378 in February 2019, a 1.9% increase Y/Y from February 2018, according to @SentierResearch.
According to @GordonGreen of @SentierResearch, as of November 2018, median annual household income reached $63,554, a 4.3% increase from January 2000, adjusted for inflation.

.@liebersohn and @rothstein_jesse estimate that since rate hikes began in mid-2021, “around 1,000,000 fewer people with a mortgage moved than would have if there had been no rate lock,” resulting in a deadweight loss of $20 billion per year.

The drop in Japan’s net private saving rate since its 1974-75 peak is due to the steady aging of the population and in recent years, more rapid spending down of wealth by retired elderly households. @CharlesYuji
US growth slowed by 36% from 1964-2009 due to housing supply constraints in high TFP cities like New York & San Francisco.

US data since 1919 shows that volatility in building permits foreshadows financial market volatility. “Cities and states with more elastic housing supply consistently predict financial market downturns at 12-month horizons.” @cslapoint @CortesGustavoS
Superstar cities see faster house price growth but lower total returns due to higher rental returns in more remote locations. National superstars trail national averages by 90-100 basis points.

Brooks expresses alarm at the “unprecedented” sharp rise in market-implied Japanese and European forward yields at the long end, “as the debt crisis in the Eurozone still festers.” The “less worrying” picture for the US is likely a safe haven effect.

Pew and Center for Immigration Studies likely overstate immigration outflows from the US because the CPS calibrates to match out-of-date population estimates, and because non-citizen response to the CPS has dropped 18% since November.
If half of the Nvidia chips sold btw February 2024 and February 2026 are employed in the US, that alone will increase power demand 25 GW. The US added 27GW of energy production in 2023.
A dollar of unearned income reduces pre-tax earnings by ~50 cents; a UBI of $12,000 a year would reduce average household earnings by more than $6,000.

As AI-related investment has risen since 2023, residential and nonresidential investment have declined or flatlined. This may suggest that a relatively rate-insensitive AI buildout is crowding out more interest-sensitive forms of investment.

Over the past 50 years, federal spending has averaged 21.1% of GDP, rising to 24.4% post-pandemic. Revenues, at 18.3% of GDP, remain above the 17.3% 50-year average, but not enough to cover interest costs and “relentlessly” rising Medicare and Medicaid.

In 2024, BYD sold 4.27mm cars, a 10-fold increase in four years; 1.76mm were pure EVs, almost on par with Tesla’s 1.79mm. Over those four years, Tesla’s production rose only 3.6x. Both firms are focusing on autonomous driving.

As measured by tonnage, China built 57% of ships globally in 2024 and has 59% of outstanding orders going forward. While it lags in production of the most complex ships, it still has ⅓ of the LNG orderbook.
Enormous government subsidies for EVs are reducing Chinese oil demand, which is expected to peak in 2027.
An Australian analysis of the top 10% of high-quality scientific publications found Chinese researchers have surpassed American researchers across 8 critical technology domains.

The cost per watt of the newest nuclear plants in the US is $15, relative to $1.67-$2.58 per watt for Chinese nuclear plants under construction. Since 2013, the US has built two new nuclear reactors while China has built 13 and has 33 underway.

China is undertaking a large-scale infrastructure build on its eastern coast, including new naval bases for amphibious vessels with hardened fuel tanks. Michael Dahm, a retired U.S. Navy intelligence officer, argues “they expect this to be bombed.”
Innovation drove 70% of TFP growth from 2003-2013, while creative destruction contributed 22% and new varieties added ~5%. @PeteKlenow

The US prime-age employment-to-population ratio and the job-finding rate for those in the labor force are ~at the European mean. But the US participation rate has fallen below 90%, on par with Italy at the bottom of the pack, driven by men ages 25–34.

Robin Brooks argues the “unprecedented” immigration wave under Biden “collided with a segmented labor market that was leaving more and more people on the sidelines.” He implies the marginal native male worker is worse off due to increased competition.

Robert Gordon finds that presidential approval ratings in 1973-1983 were persistently reduced by high inflation and unemployment, while “the post-Millenium decline in average approval” is dominated by “non-economic contributions” such as polarization.

A study of long-haul truck drivers finds that the 44% concerned about losing jobs to self-driving trucks are most likely to “double down” on investment in trucking, particularly when they overestimate the cost of retraining. @MichaelRStrain @stanveuger

A year after a Chinese “5 Year Plan,” employment, investment, and output of US establishments in industries designated by China for increased subsidies begin to drop significantly, followed by plant closures.

An experiment using repeated random assignments of managers finds that good managers have twice the impact on team performance as good workers. Randomly assigned managers do better than self-nominated ones. @ProfDavidDeming @SoniaBhalotra @_farahsaid

Parental divorce has persistent, and mostly negative effects on children. Both boys and girls have lower levels of educational attainment, while boys are more likely to die early, and girls are more likely to have children at an early age.
“Much of the $40 billion of chips the US imports are actually made in the US, packaged abroad, and reimported,” Chris Miller argues. Thus “tariffs would senselessly penalize domestic manufacturers.”
COVID cash transfer impact study yields null results: RCT (n=5000) shows one-time payments ($500/$2k) fail to improve financial/psychological/health outcomes despite short-term spending boost.

.@Brad_Setser @SanderTordoir note that the EU has 30mm manufacturing workers, 2x what the US had before the 1st China Shock, and argue that for the EU a 2nd China Shock “will be associated with the loss of export markets, not just a surge in imports.”

In 2015, federal and state educational spending revealed a $1,013 per-student disparity favoring poor students, totaling $10.4bn. Despite targeted funding of $67.8bn for poor students, the larger non-poor demographic led to $219.9bn more spending on them.

Treasury market liquidity, whether measured by bid-ask spreads, order book depth, or Treasury price volatility, sharply declined in response to the April 2 tariff announcement, but quickly recovered after April 9, when the tariffs were mostly postponed.

Over 2019–2024, 2nd-generation immigrant black female workers had earnings as high, or higher, than (non-hispanic) white women; 2nd-generation black male workers earned 10% < these white workers at the median, but this gap disappears at the top decile.
At the lower bound, the economy cannot maintain equilibrium unless output falls.
The federal financial safety net has expanded significantly, covering $25tn in financial assets, a substantial portion of the U.S. financial system.
Airbus is now at par with Boeing as measured by cumulative deliveries, though the A320 launched 20 years after the 737. Boeing still leads in larger wide-body aircraft.
"There are still more criminals than you might expect." 6.2% of white American men, 14.4% of hispanic men, and 26% of black men born in 1991 will have been imprisoned by the time they turn 50.

Biden’s benefits package could provide a family of four with two unemployed adults an after-tax income exceeding $135,000 in Kansas and $170,000 in Massachusetts, surpassing 85% of household wages. This may reduce employment by 5-7m, or over 8m if the $15 minimum wage is included.
California now has 13GW of battery storage capacity and plans to add another 8.6GW by 2027; the batteries consistently supplied 25% of the state’s electricity during the spring and summer peaks.

When applying U.S. income standards to Western Europe, the middle-class share shrinks significantly, highlighting disparities in living standards. In 2010, U.S. middle-class incomes ranged from $35,294 to $105,881, adjusted for cost-of-living differences.
Education boosts intelligence by 1-5 IQ points per year, according to a meta-analysis of 142 effect sizes from 42 data sets involving over 600,000 participants.

Until the TCJA, the top 400 US individuals by wealth and the full US population both had effective tax rates of ~30%. The TCJA reduced the Top 400 individuals’ total ETRs to 23.8% in 2018 - 2020, well below those of the full population.

A correction on the scale of the dotcom crash, when the S&P 500's value relative to the size of the economy fell by 53pp, would reduce household wealth by 8% and have a larger impact on the economy today due to households' increased exposure to stocks.

.@swinshi notes that @JacobBastian25’s latest research underestimates the disemployment effects of an enhanced Child Tax Credit. Scott view of the disemployment effects support Bruce Myers and @kefincorinth CTC estimates @UChicago. @aei

Kevin Corinth finds that childless, non-disabled, non-working adult Medicaid recipients aged 19–64 spend 14.4 hours a day sleeping and watching tv/video games, 3 hours more per day than their working peers.

Given that deflation is becoming entrenched in China, Robin Brooks argues that the US has the upper hand in the trade war. He cautions that easing up on China's exporters while China's hold on rare earths is undiminished, undermines the US position going forward.

As of July 2025, ChatGPT was used at least weekly by ~10% of the global adult population. 70% of usage was non-work related. Work usage was most common for educated users in high-pay professional occupations.

While the dollar’s weakness is likely being driven by the same fiscal deterioration that is spiking long yields in Germany and Japan, the imposition of tariffs had a real impact on the US's convenience yield relative to other safe havens.

Between 2000 and 2018, high-income cities had greater income growth, raising the relative demand for housing in them. Because these cities also face more geographic and regulatory obstacles to new housing, house prices and rents rose in the aggregate.
Sweden's market reforms: Govt spend cut 70% to <50% GDP, debt 80% to 41%, corp tax -6pts to 22%. Results: Growth +1pt vs EU since 1995, GDP/capita now at 85% of US. Ranks 15th in economic freedom.
Barclays estimates that AI-related investment constituted half of America’s 1.6% annualized GDP growth in the first half of 2025.

U.S. labor market remains historically tight, with a significant employment shortfall persisting through 2022. Key factors include Covid-19 health concerns, immigration restrictions, excess retirements, demographic shifts, and reduced incentives to work.

Rising inequality in the US has led to a savings glut among the top 1% and dissaving among the bottom 90%, creating economic fragility. To escape this debt trap, shift income distribution to foster sustainable demand or consider equity financing for housing and businesses.

To counter Chinese style “persistent, policy-engineered surpluses—designed, e.g., to boost a country’s manufacturing share by suppressing wage growth,” Pettis proposes a “global customs union open to all countries that commit to balanced trade.”

As inheritances in the rich world rise to gilded age levels, Victor Haghani and James White calculate that an optimal mix of stocks and bonds since 1900 would have yielded 10% per year, exceeding the 6.6% from an all-stock strategy, with less volatility.

Substrate, a US startup, has invented a new X-ray lithography tool; if its performance claims are borne out, “leading edge wafers [could be] produced at 50% less than existing options,” disrupting both ASML’s and TSMC’s effective monopolies.

.@paulkrugman argues “if we believe our numbers, which maybe we shouldn't, but if we believe our numbers, total factor productivity growth has been really pretty lousy" for the last 20 years, even with significant technological changes.

The IMF argues that a well-designed tax on income from capital, at a lower rate than labor income, would be less distortive and more equitable than a wealth tax if countries seek to raise more revenue from the rich.

Japan's non-Japanese population has surged to 3.5mm, 3% of the population. By 2026, there will be 1mm Chinese nationals living full-time in Japan, largely middle-class Chinese - a phenomenon referred to as Run-ri.
The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (TCJA) saw the top 1%'s contribution to federal individual income taxes rise to 40.1% in 2018, up 1.6pp from 2017.

Robin Brooks argues China's record good surplus overstates the strength of its export sector. Brooks suggests that the effect of tariffs has been to suppress Chinese margins, as exporters cut prices to sell to the non-US market.

Treasuries must be an asset that “can be quickly liquidated for cash” in a crisis. Treasury markets are “growing too large to rely exclusively on dealers to intermediate” these trades, and require central clearing and “all-to-all” trading, Duffie argues.
10-year gilt yields are the highest across the G7. Goldman estimates the UK needs a fiscal consolidation of ~ 3% of GDP to attain a primary balance of ~1% to stabilize debt.
A progressive wealth tax could target the top 0.1% of wealth holders, who own 20% of US wealth. A 2% tax on wealth btw $50m & $1bn, and 3% on wealth above $1bn, could generate $2.75tn over a decade.

Federal savings from extending Medicare coverage to include weight loss drugs like Ozempic and Wegovy won’t remotely offset the cost, which @USCO forecasts at $35B between 2026-2034. Over ⅔ of current Medicare beneficiaries are overweight or obese.

A New York Times analysis of the NYC democratic primary electorate found a significant shift in voters’ age profile. While < 50,000 people 18–24 voted in 2021, the participation of that cohort tripled this year.
Hsieh-Moretti's estimate of GDP gains from urbanization is significantly larger than previously thought, with corrected estimates suggesting GDP could be 36% higher over 45 years.

Bor, @Cutler_econ, Glaeser, and @lj_ristovska find a strong negative correlation between the % of college graduates in an area and all-cause mortality, even after controlling for individual education.
Equity Based Compensation ~45% Of Total Comp Of High-Skilled Labor, Including It In Labor Share Cuts Decline of Labor Share Since The 1980's By 60%.
Research indicates running a "high pressure" economy can mitigate hysteresis effects by encouraging higher labor force participation & investment. @ValerieCerra

Brad DeLong suggests that AI investment is largely defensive in nature, “with fear of AI‑driven disruption defining the moment,” and is skeptical regarding its prospects. ”What, concretely, are the ‘new-and-improved’ services that justify the AI boom?”
IBM Quantum Starling aims to achieve 20,000x the compute of current quantum computers by 2029, leveraging advanced error-correction techniques to ensure fault tolerance.
An analysis of recent CPS data by the Center for Immigration Studies suggests that there were 14.8mm illegal immigrants in the US in May 2025, 1mm fewer than the Center’s January estimate.
@KirstenFleming US Trust study: 77% of wealthy respondents said they grew up poor or middle class, Fidelity study: 86% of wealth is self-made.
IMF data shows a significant decline in the cost of capital goods, with shares and relative prices of investment categories shifting in response.

Immigrant entrepreneurs outperformed native entrepreneurs in US high-tech sectors, exhibiting higher innovation rates across various metrics, including product and process innovation, according to @JDavidBrown @nberpubs.

Immigrants accounted for 15% of the 2020 US population, but 27% of new businesses formed in 2021-23. Differences in education and fields of study only partly explain immigrant firms’ high rates of patenting and innovation. @william_r_kerr @schodavadia
Immigrants have started more than half of the nation's $1bn+ startup companies, creating 760 jobs on average per company & holding a value of $168bn, nearly half Russia's stock market value.
Immigrants in Norway, Sweden, and Denmark face significant integration challenges, with lower labor force participation rates compared to natives. In Norway, immigrant LFP is 61%, vs 76% for natives.
Immigrants start firms at higher rates than native-born individuals, expanding labor demand more than labor supply, according to @BenjaminJones and the @nberpub.

Immigration in Europe has increased by 50% btw 2000 and 2015, with two-thirds of growth from outside Europe. This shift correlates with a decrease in support for redistribution among European-born voters, particularly center-right voters.

.@WendyEdelberg, @stanveuger, and @CecEsterline estimate that the four-year growth in the total civilian non-institutionalized population over age 16 could range from 5mm to 15mm, depending on the impact of the election on immigration.

Revised projections of net migration for 2025 span a range from −525,000 to 115,000, “reflecting [an] expectation of severely curtailed inflows” and only “somewhat” higher outflows, strongly weighted towards large negative net flows. @stanveuger @AEIecon

Between 2000 and 2019 a @giov_peri @ale_caiumi analysis finds immigration had a positive 1.7-2.6% impact on US non-college workers' wages, as high-skilled immigrant labor complemented low-skilled native labor.

An analysis of 17 Chinese industries from 2006-21 finds that a 1% increase in industrial robots per 10,000 workers (robot density) raises nominal labor productivity by 0.018%, with evidence of diminishing returns.
Family-managed firms in Spain raised productivity faster when exposed to import competition, especially those with multigenerational family ties. @ChengChen

There is evidence the opioid epidemic was a supply shock: states with higher levels of imports, and more opportunities for smuggling, saw higher levels of fentanyl deaths between 2017 and 2020. @benconomics
Illegal economy impact substantial: Drugs = 5% of 1980 PCE, now $111bn GDP contribution (2017). Illegal sectors grew faster than GDP, buffered 1970s/post-2008 productivity slowdowns.
Expansionary monetary policy boosts employment for workers with weak labor force attachment, such as Blacks, high school dropouts, and women, especially in tight labor markets.
Fiscal Response To Covid Pandemic Reduced Poverty Rate By 1.5 Percentage Points, or 14%.
Median household increased 6.8% in 2019 hitting $68,703, poverty rate hit’s record low.

In the SCF, the wealth share of the top 0.1% of the wealth distribution rose from 10.6% in 1989 to 14.7% in 2022. Adding the Forbes 400 to the sample yields an increase from 12.2% to 17.1%. The Forbes 400 share rose from 1.8% to 2.8%.

US labor market polarization driven by shift in labor demand towards higher income elastic sectors, affecting high & low-skilled occupations. Btw 1980-2016, this shift accounted for 90% & 35% of wage-bill share increase for low- & high-skill jobs, respectively.

Mogstad et al find that over 70% of the difference in earnings variability between the Nordic countries and the US/UK is due to a lower skill premium rather than skill variability, likely the result of wage compression due to collective bargaining.

Urban income study: Downtown housing costs driven by top earner influx; welfare gap btw 90th/10th percentiles widened 18% points (1990-2013). Higher-income residents' spatial preferences amplify inequality
Real median household income was $83,730 in 2024, effectively flat from 2019's $83,260.
Rising debt levels transfer income from borrowers to savers, depressing aggregate demand. Debt service payments increase, borrowers reduce spending, while savers don't fully compensate. @AmirSufi

New @KurtMitman study on Missouri's 2011 UI duration cut reveals a 11.1% increase in job finding rates, driven by heightened search efforts & labor market tightness. The elasticity of job finding rates with respect to UI durations was -0.45.

Jonathan Sine argues China’s global manufacturing share is likely near its peak as growth has slowed from 1.5% to 0.5% btw 2010 and today due to deglobalization and intensified countermeasures against Chinese industrial policy.

Chris Miller asks, "How much inefficiency should we swallow in exchange for the security of self-sufficiency?" He argues it's "a tricky calculation" as "security gains are probabilistic" and "long-term economic costs are highly speculative."
Industry components account for ~62% of the increase in earnings inequality and 73% of btw firm inequality growth.
Research by @AdrienAuclert suggests that shifts in income distribution have minimal impact on aggregate consumption, with a MPC gap of < 0.1% btw top 10% and bottom 90% earners.

Chetty's mobility data, when scrutinized for uncertainty, reveals significant limitations in its robustness. While conclusions about academic achievement across countries remain stable, findings on intergenerational mobility in the U.S. are less reliable.

Nationally, real house prices are now 2% below the 2022 peak and 10.5% above the 2006 peak. “Affordability” remains at levels last seen in the early 1980s when 30-year mortgage rates were over 14%. @calculatedrisk

Nationally, real house prices are now 2.5% below the 2022 peak and 10% above the 2006 peak. “Affordability” remains at levels last seen in the early 1980s, when 30-year mortgage rates were over 14%. @calculatedrisk
Nationally, real house prices are now 2.7% below the 2022 peak and 9.8% above the 2006 peak. “Affordability” remains at levels last seen in the early 1980s, when 30-year mortgage rates were over 14%.
Nationally, real house prices are now 2.8% below the 2022 peak and 9.6% above the 2006 peak. “Affordability” remains at levels last seen in the early 1980s, when 30-year mortgage rates were over 14%.
Evidence from German investors finds that educating investors about negative stock market returns during inflation causes them to reduce their return expectations and purchases of equities.

Since 2019, American households have accumulated $59T in net wealth. Overall household net worth could finance 8.5 years of current spending. “Lowering interest rates would be…particularly risky given the financial position of American consumers.”

Wage growth for the typical US worker has been steady at 1–1.5pp above the pre-pandemic level, paralleling inflation. Matt Klein argues Trump’s desired 300bp drop in the FFR to lower the costs of debt service would be "extraordinarily inflationary."

In a trial with 50 physicians to test the impact of GPT-4 on diagnostic accuracy, the median diagnostic reasoning score was 76% for the GPT-4 group and 74% for the conventional resources group. GPT-4 alone scored 89%
IT, not anticompetitive measures, is driving industry consolidation. Top firms benefit from enhanced performance metrics, contributing to a widening productivity gap btw leading firms and others.
The cost of building one mile of interstate highway in 1980 was 3x the cost in 1960, adjusted for inflation. @LeahBrooks, Brookings Institution.
A treatment that inhibits the pro-inflammatory cytokine IL-11 extends the median lifespan of male mice by 22.5% and of female mice by 25%, and may inhibit aging pathologies in older people.

French workers who joined the technology sector from 1994-2002 earned 6% lower wages 15 years out relative to similar workers starting in other sectors, presumably driven by faster skill obsolescence. @johanhombert @AdrienMatray

Europe allocates 53% of its R&D to the automotive sector, yet its global share of superstar firms has halved since 1999. Europe's private R&D investment is only 19% of the global total, trailing behind China & the US.

At ~3:1, the ratio of nonfinancial assets to liabilities is at its highest level since 1985. Since Covid, Americans in the bottom 60% have seen an ~43% rise in the value of durable goods owned relative to consumer credit owed, the highest across cohorts.
According to Bank of America internal data, median annual property insurance (auto and housing) payments have risen from 4% of household income to 5% over the past four years.
Intangible capital plays a significant role in economic growth for both the EU and US, with data showing intangibles account for 20-25% of market sector labor productivity growth in Europe.
Markups and intangible capital explain somewhere btw 1/3 to 2/3 of the measured productivity slowdown during the 2000s.
U.S. gross migration rates have fallen modestly over the past 50 years, but net migration has hardly budged. "On average, only 10–12 out of 100 moves reflect a net flow from one location to another."

The 10-yr TIPS break-even, at 2.3%, is only 20 bps above its 20-year mean of 2.1%: expected inflation is anchored, but the cyclically adjusted E/P ratio minus the 10-yr TIPS yield, a measure of the equity premium, is at worryingly low June 2007 levels.
American mobility is generally lower than in Canada, primarily due to low mobility levels in the American South. Excluding the South, US mobility aligns more closely with Canadian levels.

Research by @GuglielmoBarone @SauroMocetti shows that the same families in Florence have maintained wealth & status over 6 centuries, with earnings elasticity of 0.04 & strong real wealth inheritance. Published in @AIEL_Italia.

.@leah_boustan et al. study children born in 1979-83 in 15 countries, and find that absolute economic mobility is strongest for sons and daughters of immigrants in destinations that are historically “immigrant-receiving.”

Immigrant children in the US have consistently demonstrated higher upward intergenerational mobility compared to children of US-born parents, moving 5-8 percentiles higher in income rank from the 25th percentile.

.@swinshi proposes a new price index to remove biases that overstate cost of living increases and finds that from 1979 to 2021 real market income for a middle-quintile household with children increased 59.9% vs. 35.3% under PCEPI and 12.4% under CPI-U.
WWII R&D impact: Counties with 2x OSRD patents see +60-65% tech employment by 1970s. Wartime innovation clusters drive long-term regional economic specialization. @nberpub

The global stock of investable assets is valued at $261T, or ~ 200% of world GDP, up from ~75% in the 1990s. The weight of equity relative to bonds is higher than it was post-GFC, but below 1990s levels.
Patent data highlights key technological revolutions from 1842 to 2022, with railroads, steel, automobiles, and internet driving economic transformation.

A study of 51 large U.S. ports over 2010-2021 indicates that only 15 ports would deliver a positive return on infrastructure investment, driven in part by high congestion at the port and the potential to relieve congestion at other ports. @myrto_kaloup

“Jitters over Silicon Valley’s boom in spending on AI have spilled into the bond market.” According to BAC data, a basket of bonds issued by the major hyperscalers has seen an uptick in its spread over Treasuries to 0.78pp, up from 0.5pp in September.
Sophisticated investors achieve better returns than unsophisticated investors due to their ability to access & process superior financial information, leading to capital income inequality.

New evidence from @SabrinaHowell shows US angel tax credits increase angel investments by 18% & individual angel investors by 27%, but don't impact professional investors' decisions, instead favoring low-growth firms.

The debt of several blue-chip firms, including Microsoft in the US, Siemens in Germany and LVHM in France, trades at lower yields than the underlying government benchmark, as “tough fiscal compromises” look unlikely.

“Educationally similar” monozygotic (MZ) twins raised apart [TRA] have a mean IQ delta of 5.8 points, ~ the same as those raised together. “Educationally dissimilar” MZ TRA have a delta of 12.8 points, closer to non-twin siblings than twins reared together.
Ireland's free college experiment has led to a decline in its universities' international rankings, highlighting potential pitfalls for similar policies elsewhere. @JasonDDelisle.

Azhar & Warren conclude that the AI buildout is a “demand-led, capital intensive boom,” not a bubble, given capex relative to GDP and revenue, revenue growth, and funding quality. If revenues grow at half their 2024 pace, they will reach $100B by 2026.
The rate of performance improvement of large language models may be slowing, as models face both data availability and compute constraints. GPT-5’s launch underwhelmed many in the sector.

Since ChatGPT launched, Adzuna data shows a 43% decline in US entry-level job postings requiring a degree. An FT analysis finds "no clear correlation" btw an occupation’s potential exposure to generative AI and a loss of young workers btw 2022–2024.
Among religious Americans aged 18–39, 57% and 66% of women and men, respectively, report wanting children someday, compared to 33% and 31% of their non-religious peers.

A commuting zone 125 miles farther from the closest pre-2007 AI hotspot has 17% lower growth in AI jobs’ share of vacancies over 7 years. A hotspot is defined as having 1,000 AI-related publications and patents related to “deep learning.”

Analysis by @JenniferHunt shows that the "hollowing out" of middle-income jobs is driven by demand for high-wage workers, not middle-wage workers becoming low-wage workers. Data suggests upward mobility, contradicting employment polarization.

Following tepid reactions to the release of GTP-5, Joe Wang observes, "It is looking more like companies are spending hundreds of billions on rapidly depreciating GPUs that produce a commoditized product that most clients only modestly benefit from."

Technological rivalry raises obsolescence risk, reducing the time over which adjustment costs can be recovered and thus reducing firm growth in response to innovation, reconciling an increase in the rate of innovation with a slowdown in aggregate TFP.

Rising market concentration does not inherently lead to reduced competition or hinder productivity growth. Data shows that from 1997 to 2012, the share of sales by the top 4 firms in U.S. industries increased from 38% to 43%, yet productivity growth remained stable.

Analysis of firm and establishment-level data from Korea shows that software and labor are substitutes and that the rise of software accounts for two-thirds of the decline in Korean labor share of income between 1990 and 2018. @NBERpubs
American public corporations have seen significant volatility in equity value since 1999, with a notable shift towards fewer, larger, older, and less profitable firms.
Children entering labor market today have same chances of moving up income distribution relative to parents as those born in 1970s.

US investment has been lower than predicted by fundamentals since 2000, driven by decreased competition & increased market concentration. Europe's investment aligns with profitability & Tobin's Q, except during crisis peaks.

Israeli officials credit the US Thaad missile defense systems for saving thousands of lives during their recent war with Iran. The US fired ~25% of its stock during the 12-day war. Each missile costs ~$13mm, DoD has budgeted to buy 37 over the next year.

IT investment is higher in high-wage cities, driving job & wage polarization. From 1990 to 2015, a 21.4% increase in local price index correlated with a $107.43 rise in average IT budget per worker. @JanEeckhout
School desegregation significantly reduced the test-score gap btw black and white children, cutting it in half for some black age groups without harming white children.

Italy’s population decline is among the most acute in Europe, per Istat, and ~191k people left the country in 2024, the highest level in 25 years. 50% of leavers in 2023 held a college degree, creating “a significant deficit of qualified human capital.”

An upcoming vote might provide an easier path to Italian citizenship for 5.4mm legal foreign residents, addressing the demographic challenge of a population where 25% is over 65. 13.5% of new births in Italy last year were to foreign parents.

BLS’s American Time Use Survey shows that 15 to 25-year-olds spend 26 fewer minutes a day socializing than they did in 2003. For the first time ever, adults 50 and older spent more time socializing in person than teens and young adults.

Since 2023, foreign investors have bought a net $1.2T of coupon Treasuries, or 1/3 of the net private coupon supply. The falling dollar and rising yields abroad will likely reduce foreign demand for Treasuries and “ultimately force lower fiscal spending.”
DEI impact assessment reveals key gaps: Mandatory training shows null/negative effects. Racial wage gap analysis: Black-white male earnings gap -39.4% narrows to -10.9% adjusted for education.
The CBO projected 3.3% real GDP growth for 2018, but actual growth was 2.9%, suggesting a smaller-than-anticipated effect of the tax revision.
Japanese long bond yields rose, with the 20- and 30-year hitting 2.6% and 3.2%, respectively. Globally, long yields are rising. The US 30-year Treasury is approaching a 5% yield.

Japan's new Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi has unveiled a plan to raise defense spending to 2% of GDP by this spring. If this goal is met, the plan would achieve Tokyo’s 2% defense spending target two years ahead of the current trajectory of March 2028.

Births in Japan fell to < 700,000 in 2024 for the first time since records began in the 19th century, 15 years ahead of the IPSS median forecast. Analysts are urging the government to use lower birth data for policy analysis.

Brooks argues BoJ intervention is still "massively" distorting Japan’s long-term yields, noting that Japan, with debt at 240% of GDP, and Germany, with debt at 65% of GDP, both have ~ the same 30-year government bond yield.
Yields on the 10-year JGB hit 1.78%, the highest level since June 2008, as investors anticipate further fiscal expansion in Japan.
The Japanese 30-year yield is still below Germany’s, despite Japan's debt/GDP of 240% relative to Germany’s 65%. The Bank of Japan is currently engaged in a yield control effort to manage rates.

In 2025H2, BoJ was a net seller of JGB’s to the tune of 2.6% of GDP, as maturing debt exceeded mean gross monthly purchases of ¥4.7T. A planned reduction in purchases to a mean of ¥2T “will likely send longer-term yields even higher.”

If Japan sticks with low interest rates, it faces a further drop in the yen and worsening inflation. Rising yields put Japan’s debt sustainability at risk. “This catch-22 means a debt crisis is much closer than people think,” Brooks argues.

Japan has so far avoided inflation and debt crises despite decades of slow growth and deficits that left gov debt at > twice GDP by “running a risky sovereign wealth fund” with maturity and currency mismatch, financed at below-market interest rates.

An ~18pp rise in female labor force participation between 2000 and 2025, an ~7pp rise in participation of seniors since 2012, and a 30-year low in youth unemployment have temporarily mitigated the decline in Japan’s labor force, which peaked in 1995.
Americans’ workforce earning <$29,000 a year is down 20% relative to January 2020 level; adjusted for workers earning more than $29K, workforce is down 13.5%.

Weak labor demand is not keeping pace with “modest” labor supply growth. Outside of the healthcare sector, job growth is now net negative. Mericle and Mei note that the impact of AI on the labor market may “not become apparent until a recession hits.”
Evidence supports "indebted demand" theory, showing income inequality exerts downward pressure on natural rates of interest (r*).

JPM estimates that since the start of the year, the Fed’s treasury holdings dropped $180B and commercial banks’ holdings have decreased by $60B. Foreign official holdings fell by $50B over the last 6 months on a rolling basis, according to the analysis.
Michael Cembalest notes the 10-year Treasury has been rising in a cutting cycle as the market anticipates the Fed’s response to a "tariff/deportation/loose fiscal agenda."
VC investments in start-ups within the same sector drop by 40% after acquisitions by Google or Facebook, highlighting unique economic dynamics of digital platforms.
