A @nberpubs analysis finds workers who are working from home in the US save an average of 55 minutes with 39% of those time savings being devoted to a primary or secondary jobs and 33% for leisure activities.  @I_Am_NickBloom

.@KaplAnalysis examines large US companies purchased in LBO transactions and finds that 71% of the companies hired new CEOs, and more than 75% of these were external hires. He concludes that "firm-specific human capital is relatively unimportant.”

.@davidautor finds that foreign-born populations were more likely than native workers to leave commuting zones that were most impacted by the China Shock.  However, the foreign-born population was concentrated in zones with low China trade exposure.
Evidence from Norway shows internet expansion reduced friction associated with finding a job and reduced the steady state unemployment rate by 14%. @AndreasKostol @nberpubs
.@DrDaronAcemoglu finds that negative externalities and excessive focus on high-margin technologies can distort the path of innovation and reduce welfare gains by 10-50%. @nberpubs

Evidence from Finland suggests that expansion of a home care allowance decreases maternal employment in both the short and long term and results in lower educational attainment and increased youth crime for impacted children. @nberpubs

.@caseybmulligan estimates that decarbonization in the US will result in recurring costs of up to $483Bper year, including $186B for auto fuel efficiency standards, and will lower real GDP by between 2-3% by 2035.

.@akorinek reports on how large language models (LLMs) such as ChatGPT could increase productivity in economics research by focusing human effort on posing questions and providing feedback and editing of drafts from LLMs.

A new @NBERpubs paper shows that newer firms have more earnings dispersion than older firms, and that this pattern accounts for a large fraction of the aggregate rise in between-firm earnings inequality. @WallskogMelanie

15% of American workers are independent contractors, according to a Gallup survey that was carefully constructed to avoid data problems that had previously plagued the space. @kgahome @BHershbein @bethtruesdale

The return to cognitive skills has declined since 2000 and there has been rising demand for “social skills.” “Jobs with the most employment and earnings growth are those where both types of skill are required.” @ProfDavidDeming
Over 10% of job listings in the Anglosphere countries now allow for remote work for at least one day a week. @I_Am_NickBloom @StephenEKHansen @pj_lambert @raffasadun @Bledi_Taska

Firms that adopted robots in the Netherlands between 2009-2020 increased output by 14.9% relative to non-adopting firms. Workers who were directly affected saw income reductions of about 1.5%. @DrDaronAcemoglu @nberpubs
Updated work by @davidautor documents that, since the pandemic, real hourly wage gains for the bottom 10% have reversed nearly 40% of the cumulative increase in inequality since 1980. @nberpubs
In the aftermath of the pandemic, real hourly wage gains for non-college workers have reversed a quarter of the rise in wage inequality since 1980. @davidautor @nberpubs

Robert Hall argues that a substantial rise in the volatility of costs can free the prices of a significant fraction of goods and services prices from the grip of New Keynesian "zone of inaction.” @NBERpubs

In Sweden men who won the lottery saw an increase in marriage formation and lower divorce risk. Female winners saw a near doubling of short-term divorce rates. @eriklindqvist1 @robertostling @Asia_terskaya

A review of shareholder letters from 1955 and 2020 finds that corporations “pick and choose the stakeholders they want to focus attention on, while emphasizing long-term shareholder value, especially in how they compensate.” @zingales
Evidence from investment in robots suggests robots are complementary to production workers and their adaptation is concentrated in hubs.  @erikbryn @CathyBuffington @ngoldschlag @jmirandal

.@ngoldschlag @ufukakcigit find that inventors are increasingly concentrated in large incumbent firms, and that incumbents often catch and kill young inventors.  An inventor hired by an incumbent firm sees their earnings increase and productivity decrease.
.@nomadj1s and @ernietedeschi present evidence showing that the expansion of the child tax credit in 2021 didn't significantly reduce labor supply in the short term.

Evidence from Belgian btw 2002-14 suggests that large firms generate significant TFP spillovers to domestic suppliers.  Firms that start a serious relationship with a superstar firm increase their TFP by 8% three or more years after the relationship is formed.
Between 1992 and 2017 the shift from manufacturing to the service sector reduced local employment concentration, even as national concentration rose. @davidautor @johnvanreenen

Using evidence from the roll-out of a new AI-based tool for customer support agents, @erikbryn @Danielle__Li @LindseyRRaymond found an overall 14% increase in productivity driven by low-skilled workers, with minimal impact on highly skilled workers.

A new @NBERpubs paper shows that parents' comparative skill advantage in math (vs. language) is significantly linked to the comparative skill advantage of their children. @EricHanushek @SimonWiederhold

Using evidence from two large retailers @RDMetcalfe @ASollaci @ChadSyverson find that individual managers, outside of firm-wide management practices, explain 25-35% of variance in store level productivity.
Owners of firms bear half the incidence of state corporate taxes with workers and landowners paying 35-40% and 10-15% respectively.  @J_C_Suarez @omzidar

A @NBERpubs study presents evidence on the market impact of LLMs. Firms with top quintile exposure to AI outperformed firms with lowest quintile exposure to AI by over 9% from Dec 1 to Mar 31. @andrea_eisfeldt @gregorschub @rainozhang

A review of relevant research suggests increased availability of immigrant household workers has had large positive effects on the labor supply of highly educated female workers and on the gender wage gap.  @cortespatico

Based on an analysis of U.S. federal tax changes between 1950 and 2006, goods-producing firms respond to tax cuts by expanding capex and employment while service firms largely used any tax windfall to increase dividend payouts. @NBERpubs

.@JoshuaLKrieger @Danielle__Li @DimitrisPapan20 examine R+D investment in drug development and find that research into novel therapies often leads to profitable opportunities in successor therapies that are closely related.

In 2018 Chinese born researchers contributed to 27% of American research papers, Chinese born researchers who had returned to China from the US contributed to 38% of Chinese research papers. @NBERpubs

36% of the top 1,000 scorers on the Indian Institutes of Technology entrance exam move overseas after graduation, and 62% of the top 100 scorers migrate. Of top-scoring graduates who emigrated, 65% came to the US. @prithwic @inaganguli

Detailed analysis by @Tfpiasecki shows that American manufacturing firms have not fully substituted foreign for domestic production, but rather supplement their domestic efforts with foreign production.
Between 2010 and 2018 firms that invested in AI shifted employment towards more junior employees with high educational attainment and technical expertise. @TaniaBabina @AnastassiaFedyk @AlexXiHe

.@NielsGormsen shows that the average firm reduces its discount rate by only .3% in response to a 1% decline in perceived cost of capital. The implication is a lower level of capital spending relative to what the decline in cost of capital would imply.

.@lee_ohanian @AEIEcon finds that China's pattern of growth in per capita GDP matches that of Japan, South Korea and Taiwan at earlier stages of their development. He forecasts that China’s per capita GDP will asymptote at 41% of the US level ~2050.

.@ProfDavidDeming finds that the college wage premium is driven by occupational sorting: workers with college degrees enter jobs with higher returns to tenure, suggesting the importance of on-the-job training.

.@KarstenMueIIer and @EmilVerner find that credit growth to non-tradable industries like real estate is predictive of a boom-bust output pattern and financial fragility, while credit to the tradable sector is associated with productivity growth.

.@DrDaronAcemoglu @davidautor show that declining manufacturing productivity growth since the 1970s can be explained by "bottlenecks" where slowdowns in TFP growth of a sector’s suppliers undermine that sector’s productivity.
Evidence from CA shows that between 2002-2016 Asian immigration is associated with a decline in white student enrollment in public schools. @leah_boustan
The increase in reported pain among Americans wasn't a linear trend over decades but was almost entirely concentrated in the 2007-2010 period among the less educated. @ramoffitt4
.@_seulakim documents the importance of the 50 largest US firms in generating novel patents that combine technical components in new ways.
New @NBERpubs paper finds that there is no empirical evidence that government spending related to the space race contributed to excess economic growth on the national level.
The rapid rise of China and South Korea's household debt to GDP ratio has strong parallels to EU and North American real-estate boom-bust cycles in 2007. @profsufi
Using a model of energy price shocks, @ludwigstraub @a_auclert find that an increase in energy prices for energy-importing economies lowers aggregate demand and depresses real incomes.

Improvement in the US debt-GDP ratio from 1946-1974 was driven primarily by primary government surpluses and distortions of real interest rates from surprise inflation and from pegged nominal rates, not overall economic growth. @AcalinJulien
Expected earnings for S&P 500 firms “fully explain observed stock market fluctuations from 1980-2022,” and help explain macroeconomic boom-bust cycles @NBERpubs

.@nberpubs analysis finds that a 1% increase in the working age share of population raises per capita income by ~ 1% and forecasts a 0.4-0.8pp drop in growth of income per capita from population aging.
Large Language Models (LLM) will likely accelerate knowledge creation by making science research and data more transparent and rigorous. @Econ_4_Everyone @brian_jabarian
Zero-sum thinking in terms of political and policy views is strongly associated with lower levels of intergenerational upward mobility. @S_Stantcheva @DrNathanNunn
Among 400,000 people who graduated from Ivy League schools between 1970 and 2021, athletes earned 3.4% more than non-athletes over the course of their careers. @NateeA1

A new @nberpubs analysis documents that the natural interest rate moves in a very wide range of 400-500 basis points across advanced economies.  There is a strong global factor in r*, such that natural rates tend to move together across countries.

Robert Barro and @Francesco_Bia find that 40-50% of pandemic-era OECD government financing came from the effect of unexpected inflation on the real value of public debt, consistent with the fiscal theory of the price level.

An @NBERpubs study finds that, unlike labor-saving technologies that drive earnings declines and job losses for all affected workers, labor-augmenting technologies disproportionately impact white-collar, older, and higher-paid workers. @DimitrisPapan20
Robert Hall and @MariannaKudlyak argue the natural rate of unemployment has fallen in the aftermath of the financial crisis to 3.5%.

Analysis by Loukas Karabarbounis finds that labor’s share of US national income declined 5pp btw 1929-2022, and labor’s share globally has declined 6pp since 1980. He proposes capital-augmenting technology as the most likely driver of these declines.

Pappada and @krogoff argue the size of the “off the books”  economy exhibits counter-cyclical variation over time, and that it represents nearly 30% of GDP in Southern Europe vs. World Bank estimates of 20%.
The decline in internal migration in the US has been driven by increasing housing prices; potential wage gains from migration are being offset by housing-related factors.

.@davidautor argues that AI can help rebuild middle-class jobs by democratizing higher-stakes decision-making tasks to lower and middle-skilled workers that had previously been the providence of elite experts.
Elisa Rubbo finds that consumer price inflation in 2020 was due to industry-specific supply bottlenecks, while since 2021 excess aggregate demand has played an approximately equal role.

During 2003-19, the mean EBIT margin of US public companies increased by 11.5% vs. 1984-2002, driven by a 47.4% increase in foreign profitability for S&P 500 firms, while domestic profitability remained flat.

A recent @NBERpubs paper confirms that global poverty and inequality declined dramatically between 1980 and 2019 and that “within-country inequality is falling on average, and has been largely constant since the 1990s” @XSalaimartin

Calomiris and Jaremski review ten famous financial crises from ancient Rome through the present and find four common factors: politically motivated subsidies, changes in investor preferences towards risk, unsophisticated investors, and fraud.

Corporate debt plays a key role in amplifying boom-bust cycles; expansions in non-financial corporate credit, particularly when backed by real estate, are associated with a higher probability of a future financial crisis.  @skalemliozcan @KarstenMueIIer

Wage returns to cognitive skill have declined for white men who took the Armed Forces Qualifying Test (AFQT) in 1997 relative to 1979, driven primarily by a decline in scores at the bottom of the skill distribution.
A new @NBERpubs paper finds that decreasing interest rates likely led to a substantial increase in the rate of retirement saving as consumers anticipated low future returns.

.@akorinek et al discuss two scenarios where AI leads to a wage collapse: if AI eventually automates all human tasks, or if capital investment fails to support automation that could potentially augment human productivity.

.@andy_garin et al. show that men born before WWII in counties chosen for large wartime plant construction earned 2.5% more per year in adulthood relative to those born in comparable regions, with benefits mainly to children born to low-income parents.

Using data from tax filers and W-2 recipients from 1998–2019, @AbigailWozniak, @john_voorheis, and @kevinrinz find that earnings for both Black men and Black women fell behind earnings for White men following the Great Recession.

Change in their relative earnings accounted for 44% of the growth in labor force exits among non-college men between 1980-2019, suggesting a decline in social status is a likely factor driving the decline in prime-age labor force participation. @BostonFed
Dependence on large buyers lowers suppliers’ wages & accounts for 10% of wage stagnation in nonfinancial firms since the 1970s.
Research from @IoanaMarinescu shows a 10% increase in labor market concentration in France results in a 0.9% decrease in wages for new hires, supporting Monopsony Theory.

“Many countries now have vast ‘contingent liabilities’ - off-balance-sheet commitments that nonetheless represent an enormous potential outlay.” The U.S. government “is on the hook for contingent liabilities worth more than 5X the country’s GDP.”

The PRC’s “China 2025” industrial policy, though far from achieving self-sufficiency, has moved target firms closer to the technological frontier. Btw 2015 and 2020, China gained a 4pp share of global patents in robotics and electric vehicles.
Slower economic growth, not rising inequality, is the primary factor behind declining absolute mobility, according to Scott Winship's analysis of Chetty's data.

.@AEI’s @swinshi revisits Raj Chetty’s data and argues that contrary to Chetty’s findings, slower economic growth has been a much more important driver of the reduction of absolute mobility than the rise in inequality.

Autor and Hanson warn the US faces a second "China Shock" that tariffs are ill-equipped to counter. According to an Australian analysis, btw 2003 and 2007, the US led China in 60 of 64 cutting-edge sectors; by 2023, China led the US in 57 of the 64.

Research by @LindsayJacobs shows that incorporating Social Security and retirement wealth into wealth calculations significantly reduces wealth inequality, with the top 5% of wealth holders' share dropping from 72% to 45%.
Americans, ages 18–24, spend more than three hours a day on social media; nearly an hour of it on TikTok. More than 116mm Americans use TikTok monthly.
Academically advanced youth show an average 9-point gain in ACT Composite scores from 7th to 11/12th grade, with growth influenced by demographic & socioeconomic factors.

Belgian data suggest that in the 5 years following “episodic engagement” with a management consultancy, firms see a 3.6% rise in labor productivity, associated with modest reductions in labor and capital input and no increase in profitability.
Analysis by @WilliamSpriggs in The Review Of Black Political Economic shows AFQT scores are racially biased, explaining only 5% of the male black-white wage gap when adjusted for bias.

Research by @NicholasBloom finds management practices account for 40% of variation across plants within same firm, highlighting significant intra-firm differences. This variation is comparable to R&D & twice that of IT on productivity spread.
The bottom 10% of firms destroy as much value as the top 10% create.

White women’s graduation rate rose 10pp more than white men’s btw the 1960 and 1980 cohorts. Returns to college, which rose twice as fast for women as men, account for 50%, and the “knock-on effect” of mothers’ rising education accounts for another 25%.

The decline in the natural rate of interest (r*) in the U.S. is primarily driven by rising income inequality rather than demographic shifts. Since the 1980s, the top 10% of earners have increased their share of national income by 10-15pp.
@greg_ip: The ultra-wealthy tax could fund socially beneficial initiatives like universal health care & student debt elimination, potentially enhancing middle-class prosperity & economic equity.
GPU rental rates at the hyperscalers are relatively stable, while overall per-hour rates for Nvidia’s H200 and H100 chips are down 29% and 22%, respectively, year to date.
Slowdown in knowledge diffusion accounts for 70% of declining US business dynamism, according to @SinaTAtes of the @nberpub.

Investor overreaction to news events may reduce market volatility: “the sum total of different individual overreactions to multiple simultaneous shocks can dampen rather than amplify their combined market impact.” @Francesco_Bia @LudvigsonSydney

David Autor's analysis highlights the decline of middle-skilled jobs that offered higher wages & benefits, but low-skilled service & retail jobs lack these advantages. Housing expenses surge, low-skilled workers face low incomes & high living costs.

Americans’ exposure to the stock market, at 30% of household net worth, exceeds the dotcom era’s 26%. The Economist’s Bird and Williams warn, “Should Digital God fail to arrive, the fall will be brutal."

The 10-year Treasury yield, relative to the trade-weighted, exchange rate-adjusted yield on 10-year governments in other advanced economies, rose over the last decade but has fallen in recent months, suggesting “many other fiscal train wrecks out there.”

Contrary to the usual presumption that increases in tariffs are stagflationary, US evidence going back to 1870 suggests that tariffs raise unemployment but lower inflation, consistent with the view that tariffs are contractionary aggregate demand shocks.

In a base model, steady state r* is still ~0, suggesting that “secular stagnation” may not be a thing of the past. AI expansion and inflation risk could each raise r* by 100 bps. Remilitarization and unfunded social spending may also push up r*.

Andrew Biggs notes that the maximum Social Security payout for a high-income couple is almost $100,000 annually, 2 to 4 times higher in dollar terms than the payouts for their peers in other Anglosphere countries.
Analysis of 5m police encounters in NYC reveals racial disparities in nonlethal force use, with police 53% more likely to use physical force on black civilians than white ones.

Unemployment for recent American college graduates is up 1.3pp since 2022. Unemployment for the generally younger group of non-college workers, measured at labor market entrance rather than at ages 22-27, has seen a 2.4pp rise.

China's household consumption plummeted from 53% of GDP in 1983 to 39% today (compared to ~70% for the US), driven by a sharp decline in household sizes and incomes as “decades of fertility-control policies have left China with relatively few children.”
According to a WSJ analysis, there were 1,135 billionaires in the US in 2024, worth a collective $5.7T. ~⅓ of American billionaires inherited much or all of their wealth.

Gold’s spot price has risen ~59% since the start of the year. Since Powell’s Jackson speech, gold has risen ~25% while the dollar has remained stable against G10 currencies in a broad debasement of advanced economies’ currencies relative to gold.

Noting that the end of the US government shutdown “has seen a resumption of the precious metals rally” with “gold and silver back to near their October highs,” Brooks concludes that “appetite for safe havens is much stronger than I would have thought.”

Looney and Yannelis tie the US federal student debt crisis to policies that filled weak institutions with students who commonly failed to complete a degree, struggled to repay their loans, defaulted at high rates, and floundered in the job market.

Bridgewater estimates that closing the ~$3T gap btw US manufacturing output and goods consumption will be an uphill battle. Largely due to manufacturing wages 7x that of China, the “US’s biggest comparative disadvantage is its cost of production.”

98% of manufacturers in the US are small-to-medium enterprises that are relatively underpenetrated by advanced technologies, including robots, additive manufacturing, and embodied AI, posing headwinds to rapid increases in US manufacturing productivity.
Megaprojects account for 8% of global GDP, with 90% experiencing cost overruns, often exceeding 50% in real terms.

Comparing restaurants in different states within multi-state commuting zones, rather than contiguous county pairs, @NeumarkEcon and team find that a 10% increase in a state’s minimum wage leads to a 3% decrease in restaurant employment after four years.

Since 2020, average electricity prices in the US have risen by ~35%, driven by a near doubling of wholesale prices, in turn due to a sharp rise in natural gas prices, demand surges in locales with constrained capacity, and transmission congestion costs.

China will struggle to address "involution," the disruptive process of relentless competition and price cutting, as excess capacity derives from China's "inability to align increases in domestic production with increases in domestic demand."

Historically, housing inventories above 5.81 months have been followed by y/y price declines 9m later. Given current inventories, Aziz Sunderji argues we will hit that tipping point in August, implying price declines would likely begin around May 2026.
Adults that use government benefits end up costing additional money, but health care and education for children show positive ROI, recouping $1 plus 47 cents for every $1 invested.
Expanded UI had a modest job search disincentive, $600 reduced employment by <.8%, $300 reduced employment by <.5%.

12% of households receive SNAP benefits, 48.5% of which live in counties that voted for Trump, compared to 51.5% who voted for Harris. Of counties in which SNAP made up > 1% of total personal income, 82.2% voted for Trump versus 17.8% for Harris.

New @nberpubs research finds that Americans are working 3% fewer hours annually in the aftermath of the pandemic.  This reduction in hours worked means labor markets are even tighter than LFP would imply.

“Good jobs” in industries that pay wage premiums became increasingly dispersed across US commuting zones over 1980-2021, find Hanson and Moretti, moving towards the South and the West, particularly benefiting Blacks, Hispanics, and immigrants.

For non-college Americans, high local prices mean lower living standards. “A high school drop-out household moving from the least expensive commuting zone to the most expensive would experience an 18.5% decline in market consumption.” @rebeccardiamond
Low-skilled workers saw almost no wage growth from 2010-2014, but then experienced rapid catch-up growth from 2014-2018.
The introduction of competitive exams under the 1883 Pendleton Act led to a decline in lower SES employees in federal positions, favoring "educated outsiders" from middle-class backgrounds.
New evidence indicates that high-quality entrepreneurship in the U.S. benefits the top 10% of the income distribution, with limited spillover effects for low-skilled workers.
Higher minimum wages were passed on to customers in high-income neighborhoods; in low-income neighborhoods, they were passed on to employers and landlords.

Data from the 2019–2021 period of US tariffs on European wines show that ~25% of the tariff at the border is paid by foreign producers, but after augmentation by markups at the distributor-retailer level, the $ pass-through to consumers exceeds 100%.
Research by @KimberlyClausing finds no robust link btw corporate tax rates and wages, with workers remaining insulated from corporate tax policies in affluent countries. National Tax Journal.

The incidence of tariffs has gradually shifted since April. Steil projects that by mid-2026, US consumers will be bearing 67% of tariffs, up from 55% today. This will leave the price level 1–1.5pp higher “than it would have been without Trump’s tariffs.”

Firms increasingly exhibit wage-setting power, challenging traditional labor market theories. Studies show wages are marked down by ~20% & more productive firms pay 0.5-1.5% higher wages for a 10% productivity increase.
Driven by the AI buildout, Google, Meta, and Microsoft’s property and equipment constitute more than 60% of their combined book value, up 20% over the decade.
Foreigners now own 40% of American equity, up from 11% in 1980 & 25% in 2000. @Steve_Rosenthal1
Based on cross-sectional data from 93 countries, low-income individuals’ redistributive preferences are more predictive of redistribution policy than elite preferences. @alain_cohn @RFisman

Paul Kedrosky argues the AI buildout may be a bubble, as unlike the railroad and dot-com booms, "capital destruction isn’t merely tolerated; it is sanctified in advance...the line between necessary excess and outright mania disappears."

Citing a rise in gold stock levels in Chinese warehouses, central bank purchases, and increased safe-haven demand from Chinese households, Torsten Sløk argues China is playing a key role in the rise of gold prices.

Brooks argues that upward pressure on global long bond yields is due to budget deficits and the fading of QE. Noting QE’s strong downward pressure on Japanese yields, he argues “there’s still lots of room for yields to rise from artificially low levels."

Manufacturing job share prior to recessions dictates their length and severity, with higher proportions leading to deeper downturns. As manufacturing jobs decline from 30% in 1950 to 8% today, traditional policies fall short.
As housing affordability has deteriorated in the Anglosphere, the share of young people (18-29) “who believe hard work brings success” has declined relative to their peers in Western Europe.

Chris Miller argues that "at the very least," Beijing's rare earth export controls will “drive up prices and make non-Chinese manufacturing less competitive” - a win for China, given its “sustained industrial overcapacity.”

Pettis argues China is unlikely to revalue the renminbi in the short term as a stronger renminbi would risk reducing export demand more rapidly than household wealth gains would increase domestic demand.
China's urban jobless rate was 5% in May. Among 16 to 24–year olds, excluding students, it was 14.9%, up from 14.2%, in May of last year.

Since February 2020, real Federal spending has risen 25%. Interest payments account for ⅓ of the increase; that spending along with increases in Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid and veterans benefits account for 77% of the increase.

The Danish Welfare Reform of 2006 linked the eligibility age for the state pension to life expectancy. Recent changes increase the statutory age of eligibility, from 67 today to age 70 by 2040, a reform that may secure the system’s fiscal sustainability.
@PaulKrugman notes that Trump's trade war failed due to a design flaw where tariffs were imposed on intermediate rather than final goods, potentially discouraging domestic manufacturing.

During the 2010s, a $1 increase in a state's minimum wage “predicts a 5% (0.3 pp) rise in the likelihood of union membership among individuals ages 16-40,” all from “groups that are not directly affected by the minimum wage.” @MichaelRStrain
New survey research shows that people dislike inflation because  they believe that it is associated with declining real wages and falling living standards. @S_Stantcheva building on @RobertJShiller

A 10% increase in parent net wealth is associated with a 2.4% increase in biological child's net wealth & 1.6% increase in adoptees net wealth, with stronger dependence at top of net wealth distribution @AndreasFagereng

.@JADHazell @jptguerreiro @ChenLian92 argue inflation is costlier to workers than the decline in real wages, as countering wage erosion requires costly conflict with employers. Workers would sacrifice 1.75% of their real wages to avoid conflict.

Noah Smith argues that manufacturing the "Electric Tech Stack" [lithium-ion batteries, permanent-magnet electric motors, and power electronics] domestically is critical due to the electrification of “everything” and drones being the "key to hard power."

Between 2008–2023, the US household and corporate sectors ran a mean surplus of 3.5% and 1.6% of GDP, respectively. "On a net basis, the US private sector does not need foreign savings," Martin Wolf argues.

.@leonardo_damico and @william_r_kerr argue that the decline in housing units per construction employee since 1970 coincided with increases in land-use regulation, resulting in “particularly small and unproductive construction establishments.”
US regional income convergence has declined over the past 30 years, coinciding with rising housing prices in high-income areas, deterring low-skill migration. @PeterGanong @DanielShoag

The US economy's consistent recovery from recessions over the past 70 years is marked by a stable annual reduction in the unemployment rate, typically around one tenth of the current level of unemployment.

Spikes in “salient” food and gas prices, along with core CPI, explain ⅔ of the surge in post-pandemic inflation expectations in the Michigan Survey, but only 1pp of the recent 8pp surge, raising concerns that expectations are becoming unanchored.

Using information available to market participants in each period, Michael Kiley finds that the decline in 10-year Treasury rates since 1990 is attributed to a decline in the expected value of short-term interest rates, with no trend in the term premium.
The US redistributes a larger fraction of its national income to the poorest 50% than any European country, with the bottom 50% receiving a net transfer of 6% of national income in 2017.

“Shifting priorities.” In a 2023 Pew study, only 22% of those 18–34 say having children is extremely or very important. For comparison, 68% say the same about having a job or career they enjoy, and 62% say this about having close friends.

Almost all measured productivity growth in US manufacturing since 1987 was in Computer and Electronic Products, but true TFP growth may be underestimated by 1.7pp in durables overall (and by 0.4pp in nondurables) due to quality improvements.
Capital deepening accounts for 44% of the slowdown in labor productivity, while TFP slowdown explains the residual.

The Dollar has fallen sharply since April 9, but trade-weighted, the US-G10 interest differential is stable. Brook argues the dollar depreciation is driven by equity outflows with bonds a "side-show,” and that dollar weakness is likely to be temporary.
Decline in labor share may be driven by software substituting for workers in cognitive-intensive occupations, particularly since 2000.
Torsten Sløk attributes the steepening of the US yield curve to accelerating Treasury issuance, an expectation of politically motivated cuts in the short rate, and a rise in expected inflation.
US wage inequality is high, particularly when analyzed by race. Data from PIAAC shows US whites have a P90/P10 wage ratio of 53.06/10.83, a wide gap btw high and low earners.
Credit glut vs savings glut: US financial sector balance sheets surge vs GDP. Data points to domestic credit creation, not foreign savings, as key driver of financial imbalances.

Thomas Philippon's analysis of American data since 1890 and British data from 1600 to 1914 reveals that technological progress has followed a consistent linear pattern, contradicting the notion of exponential growth.

Americans aged 22–45 are seeking financial stability before marrying, shifting from marriage as a starting point to an achievement after career and wealth building. This change delays marriage, increases selectivity, and lowers the overall marriage rate.

Two AAA-rated MSFT bonds trade at lower yields than their Treasury equivalents. Mackintosh suggests that the “combination of more Treasurys and fewer top-grade corporate bonds has naturally squeezed the gap btw their yields.”

Pettis asserts that in countries running chronic trade deficits, investment isn’t constrained by a lack of domestic saving, and that restricting capital inflows would not raise interest rates, while protecting domestic demand from currency appreciation.
School integration is linked to stronger outcomes in adulthood for children of all races, as evidenced by extensive research using longitudinal data over four decades. @ValerieStrauss/WashingtonPost.
Markets have priced in five 25bp cuts for the Fed but no cuts for the ECB through the end of 2026. This may reflect the 200bp ECB cuts that have already occurred or concerns about a US slowdown.

Citing excessive market expectations of upcoming rate cuts, a backlog of short positions accumulated at the height of the trade war, and momentum from this week’s 2.5% appreciation against the rest of the G10, Brooks argues “the dollar fall is over.”
Global wealth held by households, firms, and governments has surged from $160tn to $510tn since 2000, increasing from 460% to 610% of global GDP.
International Math Olympiad Medalists Who Migrate To US Are 4 to 6x More Productive Than Stayers And Migrants To Other Countries.
US tariffs may amplify deflation in China. As it seeks to replace falling US demand, China is ramping up exports to new markets at lower prices.

Citing a median 24m fwd P/E ratio across the Mag7 of 27x (26x net Tesla) relative to their comps 52x during the Tech Bubble, Oppenheimer argues valuations are “not at levels that are as high as are typically seen at the height of a financial bubble."

Young men and the unemployed report higher feelings of isolation in the Anglosphere relative to non-English-speaking countries. AI could amplify these trends if it drives “the lasting destruction of professions and careers” and long-term joblessness.

As the short-run fiscal multiplier for defence spending is likely <1, the EU’s increased defense budget will have large effects on GDP only if focused on R&D. Defence R&D is just 0.04% of GDP across the EU and 0.12% in the UK, vs. 0.62% in the US.

Between 2004 and 2022, US industries dependent on foreign inputs responded to increases in a news-based measure of Trade Policy Uncertainty (TPU) by increasing automation, leading to a rise in labor productivity with no net effect on employment.
Tech clusters now account for 34.2% of US patents, up from 11.3% in 1975-1979. Activity has reallocated from larger population centers.

While the S&P hit a new all-time high Friday in dollar terms, it remains 10% under its February 19th peak in Euro terms. The MSCI All-World Index net US has outperformed the S&P by ~10pp since February.

Increases in firm-level productivity disproportionately raise wages for top earners, and since 1980 have driven 40% of the rise in within-firm inequality as measured by the CEO/median pay ratio. @I_Am_NickBloom @WallskogMelanie @tellotri

Btw 1983 and 2013, 80% of US wage inequality was driven by within-job factors, primarily performance pay & job relatedness. Performance pay rewards individual productivity, while job relatedness reduces inequality.

During the COVID-19 pandemic, labor force exits were disproportionately high among Black and Hispanic women, driven by caregiving demands. Latinas exited at rates 6pp above White women, while Black women saw a 4-point increase.
The rise in the work-from-home share accounts for more than half of the rise in overall interstate migration since 2019, and states with greater WFH opportunities experienced more out-migration.
Technological changes have disproportionately favored college-educated workers, exacerbating economic disparities & reducing opportunities for non-college workers in high-wage cities. @DavidAutor
Automation & globalization reshape job landscapes. Middle-skill jobs fell from 60% to 45% of total employment, while high-skill jobs rose from 25% to 35% from 1980 to 2015 @DavidAutor

A measure of individualism accounts for about 1/3 of the cross-country variation in work-from-home rates, with WFH most prevalent in the Anglosphere and least in Asia. @PabloZarate98 @I_Am_NickBloom @Jose_MariaRD @cevatgirayaksoy
Nordic countries' fertility rate has declined since 2008 despite generous social transfers, as work has gained importance in individuals' lives. @LymanStone

Over 2000-2020, exposure of non-college workers, particularly young males, to college-educated workers failed to keep pace with the overall increase in college graduation rates, limiting opportunities for on-the-job learning. @william_r_kerr

Nicholas Eberstadt @AEIecon argues that given its relatively high fertility rate relative to both East Asia and Europe, the US is primed to be the world's youthful powerhouse by 2050. But to maintain this edge, the US must continue welcoming newcomers.
IMF Finds Markups Are Up ~ 8% Btw 2000-2015 And Concentrated In Superstar Firms.
Between 2011-23 electrical demand in the US increased by just 4.4%; @IEA forecasts that electrical demand will rise by 25% between 2023-35, with 60% of the growth driven by the uptake of EVs.

Global electricity demand is forecast to rise by 40–50% by 2035. Only 10% of this growth is due to AI. Coal demand, driven by power generation in India and China, is 2x its 2000 level, but will likely peak before 2035 as cleaner energy comes online.

Bridgewater Associates sold all of its holdings in the 16 US-listed Chinese firms in which it held positions. Bridgewater rotated into the hyperscalers, increasing its Microsoft stake by 112% and its Nvidia stake by 154% to 4.61% of its portfolio.
The H-1B program has been the main pathway to the US for highly skilled foreign workers. The Trump administration is switching from a lottery system to a $100,000 fee borne by the hiring entity.

A senior Taiwanese official notes that the large-scale promotion of younger PLA officers may lead to a "less risk-averse, more nationalistic and more aggressive" PLA officer corps, though the ongoing purge may impact military readiness in the short term.

China’s regulators are cracking down on “overcapacity” and “over-competition” in key industries to combat deflation. With total debt >300% of GDP and the policy rate at 1.4%, there is little room for fiscal or monetary stimulus.
China's second most senior military officer and eight other high-ranking officers have been arrested for "severe violations of party discipline" and "serious duty-related crimes."

Construction has started on a $167B (2.2% of China's 2024 GDP) Yarlung Tsangpo river dam. The project could generate ~ 300 terawatt-hours a year or about the UK’s total annual electricity use and increase GDP by 0.1–0.2 pp.

US infrastructure projects have a history of significant cost overruns & delays, with 92% of global projects exceeding original estimates. Examples include Honolulu's rail transit line & California's high-speed rail.

Trade's impact on domestic employment is minimal, as evidenced by research showing a net loss of only 200,000 jobs from 1991 to 2007 due to Chinese imports, offset by 3.3m export-driven job gains. @MichaelRStrain
Research by @AndrewBarr suggests the Post-9/11 GI Bill led to a 1.8% reduction in wages 7 years post-separation, indicating diminishing returns in a saturated education market.

About 10% of Americans aged 20–24 are not working or seeking work, nor are they in school or raising children, about twice the fraction during the 1990s. This group spends seven hours per day alone, up from five a decade ago.

The pandemic-era flight of families with young children from non-sunbelt cities ended in 2024. Sunbelt cities have seen growth over the entire period. Rural counties are now losing their aged 0–4 populations at a faster rate (-.5%) than cities (-.2%).

The 6.6% unemployment rate for new college graduates aged 20 - 24 is at its highest level in a decade, well above the national rate of ~ 4%. HS graduates ages 18 - 19 with no college averaged a rate of 14.5%, up from 13.3% over the prior 12-month period.
Tech plays a pivotal role in shaping corporate strategies & maintaining robust operating margins. Trailing 12 Month Average Operating Margin For S&P 500 Companies 1991-October 2021.
Heckman argues that contrary to Chetty’s research, local geography has little causal effect on children’s adult outcomes in the US. Studies that find otherwise reflect parental self-selection.

Analysis by @MartinKornejew shows corporate debt overhang does not significantly impact economic recoveries. Data reveals no correlation btw recession depth & business credit growth during prior expansions. Corporate debt booms do not hinder growth.

Zohran Mamdani, the Democratic front-runner for Mayor in New York City, is campaigning on ending the city’s small gifted and talented programs for kindergarten students at public schools. The program enrolls 2,500 out of 55,000 kindergartners.

Hyperscalers’ generative AI revenues were just $45B in 2024, according to a MS analysis which predicts revenues will exceed $1T by 2028. Hyperscalers’ cashflows will fund ~50% of the $2.9T projected AI buildout.
A Barclays analysis forecasts Meta, Alphabet, Amazon, Microsoft and Oracle will invest $390B in capex this year, $540B next year and $615B in 2027.

Year to date, the S&P 500’s return was 12.8% in dollar terms and 6% in yen terms; in euros, the return was - 1%. Hedged investment into US bonds and equities overtook unhedged holdings, according to Deutsche Bank.
Alberta Central, a Canadian bank, estimates Canada's unemployment rate for 16–24 year olds is 15%. The overall unemployment rate according to Statistics Canada is 6.9%.
Greg Ip argues the potential firing of Lisa Cook is a credible threat to Fed independence, noting “No president has ever tried to fire a Fed board member.”
